author: @MsLizzybusy
text: The ending of Inception is famously ambiguous: Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) returns home and spins his totem (a spinning top) to check if he's in reality, but walks away to hug his children before seeing if it falls, cutting to black. Director Christopher Nolan intended this ambiguity, emphasizing that Cobb's emotional resolution and reunion with his kids matter more than objective reality, though clues like the wobbling top and different children's clothes suggest he is likely awake, as he finally stops caring about the totem.

author: @yeyo1990
text: There was nothing ambiguous about it. Nolan's genius had the audience believing that the token was the top, when in reality it was the dream machine itself. In every scene where they wake up from the dream within the dream sequence they are hooked up to the  dream machine, this was the only scene where Cobb woke up from the dream within the dream and Nolan didn't show him being hooked up, that's because Cobb is in a coma on the plane and this is his reality. Nolan fooled everyone but a select few. That little wiggle with the top at the end was Nolan's diversion from the real token which was the dream machine.

author: @yif217
text: @yeyo1990the real token was his ring

author: @yeyo1990
text: @yif217 No it wasn't. It was another trinket that the audience fixated on just like the top. The real token was the dream machine itself, don't believe me? re-watch all the dream within the dream scenes where they come out of it. This was the only scene where Nolan didn't show it being hooked up.

author: @maskedskill
text:
Dom Cobb is in reality at the end.

Here’s why:

The Totem Isn’t Truly His

The spinning top actually belonged to Mal, his wife — it was her totem.

Cobb’s real totem was never explicitly shown (some fans theorize it’s his wedding ring, which he wears only in dreams).

In the final scene, he’s not wearing the ring, which suggests he’s awake.

The Top’s Wobble

The top doesn’t spin perfectly smoothly — it wobbles slightly, which it never does in dream sequences.

Nolan cuts before it falls, but the wobble hints that gravity is taking effect — implying reality.

Cobb’s State of Mind

Throughout the film, Cobb’s emotional barrier is his guilt over Mal.

By the end, he’s accepted her death and let go of the guilt — symbolically freeing himself to live in reality again.

The “test” of the totem no longer matters to him; his focus shifts to his children.

Christopher Nolan’s Subtle Hint

Nolan has said in interviews that the important thing isn’t whether it’s real or not — it’s that Cobb doesn’t care anymore.

However, in production notes and crew interviews, there are subtle confirmations (like the sound design team mentioning the top’s “wobble cue”) suggesting it’s reality.

author: @RayJacks-x7d
text:
So I gotta tell you all.  I became slightly obsessed with this concept before I ever saw the movie, before the movie ever came out.  This thought came into my head that I could not get rid of... It's slightly different but not much.  

It's that what if when we get to the end of our lives with all the adventure, chaos, beauty and mostly difficulty and we're simply sitting in a chair and had our eyes closed like waking up from anesthesia.  At the time I thought what if it wasn't even heaven you were waiting for but perhaps the unplug from a sort of dip into a ridiculous virtual world that took immense strength.  You look around the room slowly realizing what happened.  All your drama and worry in life now met with the realization that it was just simply like a dream.  Like having been plugged into a video game, but what you must sharpen your iron will to and resilience among other various traits to complete.  An adventure with hardship, tragedy and chaos where you play the individual.  A feet to get through where you feared death the whole time.  After a seemingly hundred years that went by only to wake up with people around you in a sort of beautiful trance just like it was a dream with all the trimmings of a ridiculously intense life but it really happened in a second.  The people around you in the chairs look at you with wonder and sort of victory as you wake up and they call you by your name and say, "welcome, you did it."  I couldn't get this thought out of my head.  For a while it stuck in me like a splinter.   As I would drive to stoplights for a bit I would reflect on it.  It was too powerful of thought to release.  Then inception came out, and it was just like the scene your seeing here.

But the movie is still a masterpiece.

author: @EstorilEm
text:
Haha the reaction of everyone in the (real, massive museum) IMAX theater when the top wiggled a bit then the screen cut to black… I’ll never forget that. 

Everyone was SOOO freaking emotionally invested into the movie at that point - especially after seeing everything culminate in that massive collective sigh of relief when they woke up on the plane…. that last scene just drew so many emotions from people. Nervous laughs, people yelling “noo!” an occasional “omg”… “you can’t do that!” 😂

I try to see all of Nolan’s movies on opening weekends, preferably in IMAX, and one thing they all have in common is the subdued yet intense conversation that all of his movies elicit from viewers leaving the theaters. I think that’s the true mark of a good writer / director.

author: @masterchief9005
text:
This somehow showed up on my recommendations despite not watching this film in over a decade. I just remember being super sad when I watched this and a line that stuck with me when watching this at that time was something like "dying a lonely old man full of regret."

Hate how true this seems to be becoming a reality for me. Soon to turn 40 and I already have so much of that in my life. Losing both my parents within a short time of each other,  all our pets, who were part of my young teenage life into adult hood. All the final goodbyes still feel surreal. As if I'm just waiting to wake up from a bad dream. How in an instant, everything I've known and loved, becomes a memory. In 5 years, I lost them all, and now life just feels empty. If only I could wake up now.

author: @eagledove9
text: This forced me to start doing google searches to find out what was the longest amount of time that a top could spin. It depends on the kind of top. The one that won the world record was a Korean wooden top, and it spun for seven hours. The type of tops that he spins in this movie might spin for a few minutes, but I couldn't get a definite answer or even an estimate as to how long. It is probably something less than seven hours, and probably less than an hour. But I don't know. The movie leaves the ending ambiguous, so we need an alternate ending where you just sit there with the camera staring at the spinning top, and nothing else, for, like, two hours, just so we can be sure.

author: @siriusdog47
text: I know there’s been a lot of debate on this, about whether Cobb is awake or not and that he ultimately doesn’t care, but for those who are still curious to know if he’s truly in reality or in a dream, the answer is in the sound of the totem. As the camera slowly pans to the totem, the sound is consistent. But in the final seconds, it starts to make a sound indicating that it’s losing its momentum. So Cobb is truly in reality and back home with his kids 😊

author: @yeyo1990
text: Cobb is comatose. Nolan made everyone think that trinkets like the wedding ring and the top were the tokens, but the real token was the dream machine itself. In every scene except this one, whenever they came out of a dream within a dream sequence they were always hooked up to the dream machine. However, in this scene, when Cobb came out of the dream within a dream, he was not hooked up to the machine. Too many people want to focus on the trinkets like the wedding ring and the top when they failed to see the obvious token of reality. Nolan is a genius.

author: @prayasjain8583
text: I know De Caprio is considered a legend but still feels he is underrated.. look at his expressions when he wakes up, get's slightly taken aback when air hostess approaches perfectly depicting our defensive mindset after a LONG nap.. then how he is stone cold in background when focus is on Fischer.. then his anger expression to Saito to remind him of the phonecall.. then the ever so slight muscle twitches at security.. looking down so Fischer don't recognize him.. then slight smile looking back at Fischer depicting "we got you in the end".. not a single word said up until that point but he conveys so many emotions so effortlessly

text: Die Droge Salvia Divinorum kann ebenfalls eine Art Alternative Realität erzeugen in welcher man über Monate oder auch Jahrzehnte "lebt" und Whhooooa....... man checkt das ganze war ein Trip und man hat vor ein paar Minuten dieses Salvia geraucht. Realität ist ein Schwamminger Begriff und egal ob traum oder leben, in dem Moment fühlt es sich echt an und man erlebt und erfährt das ganze. Wir meinen nur wir wüssten viel über unsere Existenz, aber wir wissen ein Scheißdreck und man kann mit Salvia oder DMT sehr tiefgründige Erfahrungen machen über das Dasein und es gibt unzählige veränderte Bewusstseins Zustände

author: @1nemali
text:
I can’t express how much this scene inspires me. There is no better way to depict the end of an impossible mission and the relief that comes after that. None say a word. They just look at each other one last time (perhaps). Saito wouldn’t want to remember this ever happened. 
Fischer would forever live in his confusion. He is also relieved that he could live his Dad’s dream of him choosing a path of his own. 

The rest, in disbelief of what just happened. 

The last scene is the calm after a complicated storm.

I came straight frm the airport.. didn't even have a place to live yet.. but I spent the rest of the day with them surfing on net looking for one. I didn't have nothing.. but Realizing I Had Everything. 1 of most Emotional days of my life.

author: @pjfromnyc
text:
What was the deeper meaning behind the ending scene in the airport behind the 2010 film Inception 

The ending airport scene in Christopher Nolan’s Inception (2010) is one of the most debated moments in modern cinema. The scene carries profound layers of meaning, leaving the audience with questions about reality, perception, and the nature of choice. Here's an analysis of its deeper meaning:


---

1. The Ambiguity of Reality

As Cobb reunites with his children in the airport and later spins his totem (the spinning top) at home, the film leaves us wondering: Is this reality, or is Cobb still in a dream?

The ambiguity mirrors the central theme of Inception: how we define and accept reality. The film suggests that our perception of reality is often subjective, shaped by what we choose to believe rather than objective truth.



---

2. Cobb’s Choice to Let Go

Throughout the film, Cobb is haunted by guilt over his wife Mal and his inability to distinguish dreams from reality. In the final scene, he doesn’t wait to see if the top stops spinning—he turns away and embraces his children.

This symbolizes Cobb’s decision to let go of his obsession with verifying reality. His focus shifts from questioning whether this is "real" to simply being present with his family. It suggests that what matters isn’t whether it’s a dream or reality, but what he chooses to value and experience in the moment.



---

3. The Theme of Acceptance

The ending reflects the idea of accepting the life you’ve built, regardless of uncertainties. Cobb’s journey is one of reconciliation, where he finally overcomes his inner turmoil and guilt. By choosing to be with his children without obsessing over the top, he accepts the life in front of him, whether it’s real or not.

This resonates with the broader human experience of grappling with uncertainty and finding meaning in our choices, even when we don’t have all the answers.



---

4. The Role of Faith Over Proof

The spinning top represents Cobb’s reliance on external validation to distinguish reality from dreams. When he walks away from it, it signifies a shift from needing proof to having faith in his experience.

This reflects the philosophical idea that life’s meaning often isn’t in what can be proven but in what we choose to believe. Cobb’s faith in his love for his children and his newfound peace outweighs the need to confirm the nature of his reality.



---

5. Reality vs. Dreams: Does It Matter?

Nolan intentionally leaves the ending open to interpretation to highlight that the distinction between dreams and reality might not be as important as we think. What matters is how we engage with the world we find ourselves in.

For Cobb, whether he’s dreaming or awake becomes irrelevant—what’s important is that he’s free from guilt and can finally reconnect with his children.



---

6. The Audience’s Role

The unresolved spinning top also draws the audience into the philosophical dilemma. Nolan intentionally makes us question the nature of the story we just experienced:

Was it all a dream?

Does reality matter, or is it the emotions and meaning we derive that give it value?


This blurring of boundaries between fiction and reality forces viewers to confront their own assumptions about what is "real."



---

Conclusion

The deeper meaning behind the ending scene in Inception lies in its exploration of acceptance, faith, and the subjective nature of reality. Cobb’s journey teaches us that what truly matters isn’t whether life adheres to an objective standard of truth but whether we find peace, meaning, and love in the life we choose to live.

The spinning top’s fate is left uncertain because the ultimate question isn’t whether it falls—it’s whether Cobb has found his freedom.

Both of these aren't possible in real life.

text: The last lines of the film are revealing, spoken by Cobb’s son, James: “Look what I’ve been building….we’re building a house on a cliff.” This refers to Saito’s Japanese Castle Home that he built on the Limbo shore. And so these lines could be revealing that Cobb is still dreaming and his subconscious is talking to himself and referencing things he’s experienced in Limbo.

author: @ytcmtr4917
text:
Two reasons why I think he is REALLY back:

1. Unlike a top that should spin forever, this one has a jerk in it's spin at the end that one would associate with a top that is going to stop. Plus, the sound at the end confirms that jerk in its motion.
2. In the previous versions of this scene where it's not reality, irrespective of whether he chose to look away or not, there seemed to have been a design to prevent him from running and meeting the kids. Like a memory that has broken, which breaks when the kids turn around. So, the dream state not only had his resistance, but external resistance as well - especially from the fact that he had no further memory beyond being taken away before the kids turned around. This was different, and there wasn't any such resistance. So, welcome back home Mr. Cobb!

And no. He's not. The trick to figuring it out is what happens when he spins the totem. Something that only happens in that scene, and which Nolan distracts us from by bringing the totem as the center of attention. A gem.

author: @MartyMcFly1085
text:
To be parted from your children is to never be at peace, there is always an aching and a tension.

That stamp of the passport, with a “welcome home,” knowing that you are now free, and you can go to them and hug them and love them… to be free of that pain… the suffering endured to get to that moment will be forgotten instantly.

author: @Aditya-f8t5z
text:
Even if we convert the son that never returns to the son that made his own way in life, the ungrateful daughter-in-law story, I think, is very close to the core. Without a happy ending for the ungrateful daughter-in-law storyline, the pain from that story will mix with the story of the son that never returns and the result is sky high expectations for that story's ending (the end of the son that never returns story).....

Maybe there is a ending in the meme library that closes both storylines in a peaceful and sustainable manner....Without putting sky high expectations. Because sky high expectations is another risky venture...and my family is neither capable of taking risks, nor are they in a position to finance the risk..  😊😊😊😊

I keep looking.....😊😊😊😊

author: @michaelwrenn_05
text: One of the reasons I consider this to not only be my favorite Nolan film, but also one of the greatest films I've ever seen, is this scene in particular.  I remember seeing this in the movie theater for the first time, and I was so immersed in the story, and all of the sequences that happened before this scene, and when Cobb wakes up on the plane... it was the exact same feeling I had of waking up after experiencing a very realistic dream and having to take a moment to realize my surroundings. I had completely forgotten where the "reality" of the story began, and when this scene happens, it was literally like awakening from a dream.  It's hard to explain, but it's the only film that has ever made me feel like I was actually in the film itself, and experiencing what the characters are experiencing.

author: @Solveig16
text: I just watched this again today and this part hit me in the heart and I was crying.  Imagine being on the run, never feeling safe, not having a real place to call home anymore and then . . . you suddenly realize you are about to go home, the weight of that, the emotional depth of it all.  How overwhelmingly that is.  I have not been able to return home in decades and I don't feel safe anywhere.  The gravity of that is devastating and I watched this feeling and wanting what he had, but oh so far away.  😢

author: @drake128
text:
If Fischer had been trained by an extractor making his mind “militarised” then may he not suspect the strange dreams he just had?
He is aware of extraction , how it works and is aware how to wake himself up. He might be familiar with the concept of inception ,even if not then at least the room he wakes up in has all the people he just dreamt about which may raise red flags of an attempted extraction attempt ( if he wasn’t aware of the concept of inception ).
I know he gives Cobb a glance at the baggage collection like he half remembers the dream but wouldn’t this make him slightly curious ?
Or he just thought that was one wild dream and broke up his fathers legacy .
Food for thought , the film is immense and one of my faves .

author: @starchildarryl
text: The movie was brilliant… or was it? The answer to the ending was given at the VERY beginning of the movie. The WHOLE thing is a dream. He is probably in in a coma or an Alzheimer’s patient suffering until he created this ending. But the whole movie is a dream. Remember NO one is to touch the totem or else you will never know. Well he was found on a beach they searched his pockets and found his totem while he was unconscious. So from the very beginning the very thing he tried to avoid already happened. It was touched. Game over. He doesn’t know and neither will the audience

author: @siddharthajain922
text:
The award to crack the debate of whether the end was dream or real goes to my niece (in pic). I sat with her to watch this film just to get her opinions because children's minds have a different cognitive process. In the beginning she asked why can't we see the kids' faces, and in the end they showed their faces to Cobb. Therefore it was real.
She doesn't know anything about this film. I just showed 5 minutes of this film to her.

author: @postman77
text: This may seem random but I grew up in the church and thought that was the whole religion just going to church every Sunday and eventually stopped going and started to do my own thing.  I wanted to find the purpose of life because I knew everything we worked for would pass away. Later on I had a tug on my heart to open up the Bible and saw the Jesus people talked about was completely different from what was in the Bible.  I started to draw closer to the higher power and had a supernatural encounter with him and I felt his love and peace and was indescribable and overwhelming almost but was out of this world and everything looked brand new like it was the first time seeing it when I looked outside. His name is Jesus and I’m here to tell you it’s about a relationship not religion and he is real and did die on the cross for you willingly and thinks you as the only person and was thinking of you while dying. All we chase in this life is temporary think about your eternal life.

author: @Tumbledweeb
text:
I have some questions about what you believe, if you don't mind.

1. Is Jesus all-knowing?

2. Are the Gospels 100% accurate in it's portrayal of what Jesus said and did?

author: @postman77
text: @Tumbledweeb yes, and are you talking about right now or originally?

author: @Tumbledweeb
text: @postman77 Is there a difference?

author: @postman77
text: @Tumbledweeb In differnet versions it has differenet synomns thats why im not saying 100% because I can't say that for anything material but historians say 99.5%

author: @Tumbledweeb
text: @postman77 Okay. So if Jesus is all-knowing, why did he say that the mustard seed is the smallest seed? It's not.

author: @postman77
text: @Tumbledweeb that’s assuming all seeds were the same until now but Jesus was in Israel speaking to a Jewish audience so saying a seed they never heard of would be unfamiliar but it was familiar to others and could understand

author: @Tumbledweeb
text:
@postman77 The smallest seed on the planet are orchid seeds, and they were as small back then as they are now. 

As for your argument that he was talking to a Jewish audience, there's a problem with your reasoning on that one. See, if Jesus was looking to get his point across by using information that they were familiar with, he could've said that the mustard seed was a very small seed, which would've worked just fine within this parable. But he didn't do that. He specifically said that the mustard seed was the smallest of all seeds, which it isn't. Not even close.

This leaves us with two possibilities:

1. Jesus is NOT all-knowing.

Or

2. Jesus IS all-knowing and was lying to them.

So, which one is it?

author: @Seikoingplastering
text:
Once of the finest pices of screenwriting of our time...

The question of being human itself ..is not what we believe to be real, but the inception that it could possibly all be an elaborate lie.
Our entire lives are built around  the moments we perceive & interpret of which we translate into profound emotions that stire the course of our entire lives.
But what if our dreams could be manipulated.

Did codd come home or did Saito keep him under, did they all ride the kick back up...or are they all traped 

The top keeps spinning maybe because Molly now has control of the dream..she asked cobb to stay and he refuses.

Remember in the warehouse scene..the gentleman tells codd "these people prefer the dream but who's to say its any less real they are happy" 
The dream is now thier reality.

Dare to dream a little bigger..

I was prescribed 2 antibiotics, 
At 5am every morning I would sit up, take a few breaths, brace myself and go back to sleep....
For the next hour,  I freaked out on the vivid dreams the meds were causing....
After 9 days, I stopped taking the meds,  going ashore at Normandy was one thing,  but the trains were too much,
I still have some pills left ,

author: @willorchard
text:
I always interpreted this ending differently to everybody else it seems. I see a lot of comments either 1. try to like science-fiction-work-out an answer like it's a maths problem, looking at wedding rings, what the kids are saying whatever which is just obviously ridiculous, 2. loads of people saying that he realises it doesn't matter if it is a dream or not - this is the life he wants and living it like this is indistinguishable from living it any other way. I definitely prefer 2 of course - he isn't haunted by the same concern which killed his wife, but I don't think it's correct. From the moment I first saw it I always thought the ending was simple: that he doesn't need to check it's real, he already knows it is. The love for his children show him it is real more than any totem.

I think this is reminiscent of a very famous argument by GE Moore, the 'here is one hand' argument. There is a typical skeptical argument that says we cannot know if we are dreaming, so we cannot know that (for example) my children are real. What Moore said in response was, I know that my children are real, therefore I know I cannot be dreaming. (except his argument centred on knowing the existence of his hands, hence the name of the argument).

author: @weirdwitcher
text: @dirdib69 He never really made that call though because Cobb never really woke up. That's why that thing is still spinning at the end, Cobb is still in a dream and just dreamt of Saito doing the call and everything ending in peace. Cobb was always trapped in a dream, for the whole movie. The first dream was already an inception, that's why Cobb knew it is possible. The whole story was just a dream and every dream shown was a sub-dream. Cobb's wife escaped it even though the movie tried to tell us that she went crazy and actually killed herself. She didn't, she escaped the dream and Cobb stayed in it because everything was just too beautiful to leave it behind, he lost track of what is reality and what isn't.

author: @daleblake81
text:
A lousy question actually, I can only assume you didn't pay full attention to the movie. Cobb and co spent the majority of movie time in dream world. Time in dreams go slower than in real life (according to the movie) Breakdown as follows:- 

Real world: 10 hours
1st layer : 10 x 20 => 200 hours => 8 days and 7 hours (about a week)
2nd layer : 10 x 20 x 20 => 4,000 hours => 166,67 days (almost six months)
3rd layer : 10 X 20 x 20 x 20 = 80,000 hours => 3,333.33 days => 111,11 months => 9,26 years (almost 10 years)

Hence why his kids didn't get older, duh.

author: @hiphoppacmotion
text:
I think at the ending, he ends up being in a dream. The scene of his kids with their backs to him (which is a *recurring* scene throughout the movie) is the same exact snapshot/memory of them at the last scene when he's "freed" to be with them. And *then* they turn around to reveal their faces? Surely if he was to see his kids again in reality, his first encounter with them once again wouldn't be them *again* picking grass/bugs/random shit on the ground, as his been the same exact scene of the the entire freaking movie--that's unrealistic. I thought for the longest time that the ending was his reality, but it really isn't--he's stuck dreaming because of the aforementioned reason I just gave. Also, in all the levels of their dreams, Cobb and Saito missed the timing of the kicks. So, they're stuck in limbo. 

And lastly, if the "perfect life is indistinguishable from a perfect dream" as what many people say the ending suggests, then if Cobb was happy to be in a dream in the very end of the movie, then he should have just stayed in limbo with Mal *with* their kids in that dream. So that idea makes no sense, the whole operation never needed to happen to begin with then. Cobb is in limbo at the end.

author: @marianne9221
text: Yes the ending is open to intepretations, but a logical guess should favour the bad end. Think about it, Cobb has been on the run for an extended period of time based on the atmosphere of the plot and premise, not less than year at least with an educated guess. Children grow up and change really fast when they are young, so its very unlikely they would have looked exactly the same as when Cobb left them im terms of height, and even hairstyle etc. Ofc its just a guess and the timeframe could be extremely short as opposed to what im guessing it to be, but the possibility that he really succeeded is lesser than he failed. Do also consider we never got to see what Saito did with the gun. Furthermore we've seen in Mal's case that people tend to lose track of reality in limbo. Not to say Saito couldnt have realised it himself, but he did not offer the typical resistance to accepting that his reality was fake despite spending his whole life living there and accepted whatever Cobb said rather easily. So maybe that whole scene was a construct of Cobb's mind to begin with, since it went too smoothly for Cobb.

author: @naminabantu
text:
This movie was one of the best edited and incredibly paced movies ever. The way the tension is created in the third act until the very last scene of Saito picking up the gun, and then when Cobb wakes up, It makes the audience feel like they've themselves woke up from a bad dream. A relief, just like when we wake up from a bad dream. Zimmer's music is one of the main characters in this scene that makes this scene as good as it is.
This is movie is truly an all-timer, and one of my absolute favorites.

author: @WoozyCool
text:
​@midgetwars1 The top in dream world seems to almost fall but never does. Forever spinning instead. Cobb sees his kids who are in the EXACT clothes height n weight as years ago when he left. No sane odds of that happening. The kids literally other than faces turning, not a thing changed, that's sus af.
His ring disappearing isn't meaning reality, it means he finally (with help of ariadne) made peace with mal and let go of her. 
But he still chose her totem to check with reality, hence the line "you don't know where the train will take you, but it won't matter, cuz you will be together". He doesn't look at totem, doesn't know if the train took him to reality or still stuck in dream world, but wherever he sees his kids' faces finally is fine by him.
His guilt of leaving the kids, is now lifted, cuz of successfully finishing the job that rewards him his life with kids back,
Hence his mind simply ALLOWS him to remember his kids faces being seen by him, from the past. Which he wasn't able to see until his guilt was cleared.
Meaning he did see the kids faces, just had been a blocked memory, even for his dreams being unable to access.

In the dream once, mal tries to tell him how he can indeed see his kids and they're right there, as she was calling out to the kids, but cobb sees them do the usual thing, getting up and running without showing their faces to cobb,  he tells mal to "just stop".
meaning she was right, she meant he knows what their faces looked like in that exact moment in those exact clothes, he won't let himself past the guilt of leaving them and won't let himself see, the dream world mal knew that and cobb hated how she toyed with him with that.

which is why ring doesn't mean it's reality now or that the kids faces mean reality either.

watching this movie several times with coffee spikes, let me put this together. i finally can stop the coffee and sleep now.
of course, i need to get the coffee again and go rewatch tenet, that movie is insanely good. christopher nolan is a gift that never stops giving.

author: @JB-xl2jc
text:
Interstellar's "Docking" scene is one of my favorite in all of cinema and is one of a handful of scenes that I would change genuinely nothing about. The ending scene here is another one that I'd change nothing about. The soundtrack is absolutely INTEGRAL to the success of both. 

But they can't be directly compared, at least in my opinion. The scene in Interstellar is about the triumph of mankind against adversity ("It's not possible..." "No... it's necessary.") and is bombastic and gets you incredibly fired up. This scene in Inception is about the end of a chapter of life, the feeling that you and those around you have been through so much, the feeling of awakening from a dream that feels as though it stretched on forever- and yet, just as that chapter closes, a new chapter opens: a homecoming, a return to loved ones and family members. "Welcome Home, Mr Cobb."

author: @strawberryblondemilk7249
text: I remember in 2020 when no new movies were coming out and my local cinema were playing old ones just to keep the doors open they played inception for a week not only did I get to see the film again on a proper cinema screen (the first time I saw it in 2010 was in some rundown cinema with the screen going in and out of focus abit of disastrous experience I was also to immature to really enjoy it). But in 2020 I got to see it in its perfect form my brother had never seen it before so he came too, seeing his face afterwards light up with pure enjoyment and asking the same questions I did over 10 years ago was incredible your tv at home doesn't do this film justice at all, Inception was made for the cinema a truly special film.

author: @samueldwumfour5535
text:
When people say the top was wobbling 
It doesn’t guarantee anything because regardless of what NOLAN says he himself doesn’t know if it stops or not 

What if his real reality started from whenever he has the spinning top


Hear my out 

Let’s say initially he thought he’s capable of realizing what reality is and is not so he never needed a tottem
But after he got his wife’s tottem he took it as a reality 
And then started living from there *as the real reality which is not * ?

So all the characters can be his imagination to dive deeper 
So the 3rd level is where he has the top and the 4th is when he has the ring 
He’ll always come back to the 3rd level when he had the top because that’s the only level when he has access to Mal’s top locked inside the safe

So in my opinion he’s wayyyy Farr from the real reality 
I’m just saying

author: @GipsyD29
text:
The expressions of the actors. 
Fischer in the plane contemplating tearing down his father's company. 
Arthur thinking "you son of a bitch, you did it"
Cobb stares intimidatingly to Saito
Saito be like "oh yeah, hold up" and does his end of the deal
Cobb like "...wait for real?"
In the airport, when Cobb walks past Fischer, he's like "...he looks oddly familiar"
I still remember the audible gasp/groan in the cinema as the ending cut to black. Absolutely fantastic moment.

text:
this movie, the end, its not a dream, oh its real.
that backyard scene, he never sees his children's face thats y they're faces never showed up in his dream.
u all stuck with that top totem. well played Nolan... 

oh this is what Michael Caine said if u all still wanna argue:
In an interview with Esquire magazine, Michael Caine, who played Cobb’s mentor and father-in-law, said Nolan had explained the film to him. “When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it, and I said to (Chris), ‘I don’t understand where the dream is’. I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’
"He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene it’s reality.’ So, get that – if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream,” he added. Now because Caine did feature in the final scene featuring Cobb and his kids, it means the scene was reality and not a dream.

and yes. some still say its a dream because of the top-fadestoblack-scene

author: @donegal7
text: I watched this last night for the first time. I attempted to watch it several times before, but I was always put off by the complexity of the beginning and never really gave it a chance as I was going into it with predisposed negative thoughts. But wow... 100% in my top 10 of all time, and I like to think I have seen a lot of movies. This ending and the final scene where we finally know that he is no longer dreaming because the spinner starts to lose its balance, and he has achieved his goal of being home with his children.... Just wow. I also loved the fact that Cobb never once looked back at the spinner to see if it actually stopped or not, knowing that no matter if it was a dream or not, he was guilt free and finally content with looking at his children. That was enough for him 🥲

author: @angelfire1987
text:
Leo's only way back to the US and to his kids is to complete a mission of 'inception': planting an idea in someone's subconscious, where it mustn't appear it's been planted, or it will get rejected. 

So they take the 'mark' three dream levels deep, in order to perform the inception. In the end it all works out, and Leo's allowed home.

Mal's appearances in his dreams are a subconscious manifestation of his inability to forgive himself for her death, so she shows up constantly to sabotage the dreams, until he's able to finally let go of her at the deepest dream level of limbo. That's it in a nutshell.

author: @rossrparker
text: Every time I watch this movie, I am absolutely stunned at how it feels like I really have woken up from a dream. To suddenly remember where you are, after feeling like you've been on this huge, crazy adventure. Watching this scene gives me that exact feeling, as I forget that they were even on a plane for a few moments. It's a feeling no other film has really given me. One of the very greatest films of all time, without question.

author: @leche.fran13
text: Cobb wasn't dreaming. He was in the real world. The top was a metaphor to Cobb's dream of being with his children. He is living in his dream-with his children. Towards the end of the scene, you see the top wobble, as it slowly slows down, which reminds the viewers that Cobb's in the real world, living in his dreams.

This movie is not an open ending at all.

author: @giokspa3913
text:
@NoManSly first of all, original commenter was talking about that specific scene. The movies you listed are amazing, but even if they have incredible scenes, they can only be as good as this one from inception, because it's perfect.

Also, most of those movies might not even be better than inception in general.

author: @NoManSly
text: @giokspa3913  Lord of the rings- ride of the rohrimm, bormirs death, You bow to no one, Gandolf explains death, I am no man. interstellar- 23 years of messages, docking scene. TDK- The interrogation scene, why so serious? Schindlers List- the ending scene, Oscar finds out he could’ve saved more people. Jaws- The opening scene. Jurassic park- When they enter into the park for the first time. The Shawshank redemption- the ending scene, Andy escapes. Star Wars: a new hope- Binary sunset, the Death Star run. Stars wars: the empire strikes back- I am your father, yoda explains the force. 12 angry men- the entire movie is just one amazing scene really. No country for old men- “Do you see me?”, the coin toss. Pulp Fiction- Diner scene. Forest gump- Jenny’s death, Forest runs across America. The matrix- The red pill or the blue pill? Zero Dark thirty- ending scene. Inglorious Basterds- opening scene, bar scene. Spotlight- “Nobody can get away with this! Silence of the lambs- Literally every scene with Hannibal lector. Raiders of the lost ark- you got me with this one can’t find a better scene. Good will hunting- Robin Williams speech, “the best part of my day”, “it’s not your fault.”. Brave heart- Freedom.  The Truman show- Truman escapes. Want me to continue now buddy?

author: @JB-xl2jc
text:
This is the true lesson. So many people argue about whether he's dreaming or not in these final moments. The true lesson is that it no longer matters. For the entire movie, in truth for his entire lifetime, he's been OBSESSED with whether he's in reality in that moment. Spinning the totem like an addict, constantly reassessing his situation. 

But in that moment, he forgets the totem even exists. He doesn't care. He is home. And that's the true catharsis this scene provides.

author: @humboldtdda
text: This ending is just superb. Time by Hans Zimmer might be one of the greatest movie score songs ever. It has been transplanted over other classic Hollywood scenes most notably Chaplin’s final speech in the Great Dictator. I have actually met the owner (a prominent LA Attorney) who owns this house where the scene was filmed. Like others on here this scene is so emotional I am literally brought to tears, as I have deployed to wars multiple times and I know what reunions are like.

author: @aaronrucinski7006
text: A beautiful story that needs no defined ending because we create our ending where we go in our lives, I turn back to this moment often because it has defined my life and who I want to become. We drive our realities and our stories. Even if it all but just a dream its a dream that will be worth waking up from one day. That's the beauty of life the unfamiliarity's of what to us we consider life is simply another step in the process of existence.

Sir Michael Caine:

“When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it, and I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is'".

 "When is it the dream and when is it reality?’ He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene, it’s reality.’ So get that—if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

author: @hazchem1
text: I have a vivid memory of waking up in my cot when I was only a baby. I moved out of that house when I was only 4 and could recall to my parents where my cot was located, which was I faced in the room and the picture of the blue Rabbit at the base. I remember waking suddenly, looking at the blue Rabbit and being self aware for that period of time, before turning around and going back to sleep. I remember a  strange feeling of 'before' even although I would not have been able to articulate that. I believe that consciousness is not singular but neither is it explainable. Death is not the end, but just like the fabric of the cosmos,  it is not explainable either. It never will be.

author: @Azoria4
text: They’re trying to extract information from their clients rival by traversing into a dream within a dream within a dream all located within the rivals subconscious. If they die they’ll be stuck in limbo for who knows how long (like Leo and his wife was in the movie and because they were stuck in limbo for so long, Leo’s subconscious is very vulnerable and is compromised symbolised by his wife). At the end he frees the client from limbo, as well as himself and (supposedly) wakes back up in reality. The spinning top at the end is a cliffhanger as it’s left up to the viewer to decide whether he’s in a dream or not. Did he wake up to what is reality or is he, in fact, still and possibly forever dreaming? “Do I wake or do I sleep?” - Keats

author: @SayBiird
text:
Funny that I have just entered my thirties losing my career, my life savings (over 6 figures from gambling), and my fiancé / my love of 7 years. 

Coming to this movie for me, is finding hope that even with the odds stacked against me, it can be overcome if you give it everything you have. 

My goals have certainly been flung far away into the distance for me, and I have to begin my journey all over again alone, with a crushed spirit. 

But your success is another sign that it is possible even when you’re hopeless. Cheers man.

author: @Doctor699
text:
The best ending, everybody wins.

Robert will move forward healed from his relationship with his father due to the inception.
Saito will be able to compete with Roberts company without the threat of it becoming a monopoly.
Cobb will move forward having forgave himself for inadvertently killing his wife, and he is finally able to see his kids faces again.

It doesn't matter in the final scene if the pin top falls over or keeps going. This is the reality Cobb has accepted and it is up to the audience to decide.

author: @INCEPTUM494
text: It was The Dark Knight that made Christopher Nolan a household name, but it was Inception that proved his name alone was a selling point, and that audiences weren’t just fans of Batman and the Joker, but Nolan himself. Inception was an invitation to the filmmaker and to audiences that said (to quote Tom Hardy’s Eames), “You musn’t be afraid to dream a little bigger, darling.” An ambitious sci-fi project with an all-star cast featuring Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Hardy, Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy, Marion Cotillard, Ken Watanabe and Michael Caine, Inception blended heady concepts with crowd-pleasing blockbuster elements. It’s a cinematic union that Nolan has become known for in his efforts to create high-brow, yet audience friendly, spectacle.

author: @Aut.vincere.aut.mori.69
text:
The cut at the end is beautiful articulation of Nolans philosophy. It signifies that Cobb has let go of the insistence on an objective reality as the key purpose of life. Accepting that subjective beings have a fundamental limitation that filters the objective world through their organic lense. Submitting himself to a higher purpose root's him to sanity, humanity and meaning. 

Dispite our vast expansion of knowledge and intellect, we are now more than ever the most sickly creature to walk this earth. Infantile and nieve. Encombered by our heavy heads, we lay flat on our back, abandoned, immobile, cying out for God. The mother, the father.. whoever...

author: @freighttrain7143
text:
I loved this movie but I HATED this scene for leaving it open.

Time spent in Limbo passes SO SLOW for the mind. And Cobb did not want to be there, for so much of it.
Then back in the real world, he still never really got Mal back, and always blamed himself for damaging her.

He had suffered so much and worked so hard to get back, I wanted a BIG REDEMPTION for him very bad and was VERY disappointed when it was left unclear.

To this day, I use the scene on the plane with each of those experienced extractors all smirking and smiling and all seemingly quite sure this was real, and they had made things right - as some sort of PROOF that he really was back in the real world, and really had cleared his name with the law, and could really just live a normal life with his kids.

But it's still not certain enough. Not as certain as I felt he deserved.

author: @qual1541
text: Final kısmında çocuklar ev inşaa ettiğini söylüyor.İnşaa sadece rüyada yapılıyor.Kızın kendi totemini yaptığı sahne kasıtlı olarak yerleştirilmiş ve kız totemi hiç kullanmadı.Cobb totemi incelemek istediğinde kız ona totemi vermiyor.Cobb ise Karısının totemini kullandığını gösteriyor ama totem kişiye özel değil miydi? Yani yanıltabilirdi.Ayrıca Eşi ile araftan gerçekliğe nasıl uyandılar bir üst rüya katmanına gitmeleri gerekmiyor mu? Çünkü filmin sonuna doğru Araftan kurtulanlar hep bir üst rüya katmanına uyandı.Cobb kendi araftayken derin bir bıçak yarası almıştı.Uyanmak yerine neden tekrar arafta kıyıya vurdu ve saitonun olduğu yere gitti? Bunlara anlam veremiyorum.Cobb un karısı gerçekten uyandı ama acaba o kasa Cobb a mı aitti? Bunlar da bir seçenek tabi.Ayrıca ekleyeyim Cobb gerçek olduğuna inandığı ve eşiyle tartıştığı sahnede yine çocukları arkalarından gösteriyor.Yani Cobb aslında sürekli rüyada ve kendi paradoksunu yaşıyor olabilir.Filmin başındaki ve sonundaki sahneler aynı değil.Konuşmalara dikkat ederseniz görürsünüz “Yarım hatırladığım bir rüyada tanıdığım biri” cümlesini film başında Saito söylüyor, filmin sonunda ise Cobb.

author: @_daut7928
text:
I think what happened is real.

That being said - a lot of people who say that even if it *is* a dream, it shouldn't matter; Dom got to see his kids and was happy. I think the opposite in that case - if it were a dreanm eventually Dom would have to turn around and see the top still spinning. Even if he chooses to stay in the dream, his life is still going past without him, none of it is real... and his children would still be alone, waiting for their father to come back.

author: @sakisroubas3237
text: Cobb gets home after performing inception on Fischer, he goes to his home and starts spinning his totem to see if he really woke up or not, notices his children and can finally see their faces since he never remembered them, at that point he doesn't care if he really woke up or not, he can finally see his children, the totem can be see still spinning and troubling right before credits roll. Is it really reality? That's something Nolan leaves to the audience.

author: @Duder187
text: I saw this movie in theatres, I cant remember if it was opening night, but it was pretty close to it so nothing had been spoiled.  I remember at the end when the top is spinning, putting my hand over my mouth and leaning in closer.  When the top is the only thing in the frame and it cuts to black, there was an audible, collective gasp of everyone in the theater.  I'll never forget that.  Watching this and remembering that gave me goosebumps.  That is what the ending of a movie should do.  Perfection...

author: @johnmurphy2504
text: Single greatest movie theater experience in my life. Was in Oxford, England for a study abroad program, as I am located in the US. It is the only time I have ever seen people standing and shouting at the end of a movie. Everyone in that theater, a mix of Americans and Brits, desperately wanted that top to topple over. And yet, it would be a poorer ending if it had.

author: @nguyendaominh1078
text: I had the luck to enjoy this whole masterpiece when it came out. I still remembered how the whole theatre just went "OHHHHHHH" out loud when the lights went out after Cobb's totem kept spinning but got a bit slower. And how, literally every single person, kept discussing on whether it stopped or not leaving the theatre. Simply one of the greatest movie endings ever and such a golden time to enjoy the cinema before this "Netflix time".

author: @DavidGinnFilm
text: @MooMoo69556 Morbius is the actual GOAT. Jared Leto is the best at whatever he acts, and I can barely act like a human. Daniel Espinosa is groundbreaking, setting up a universe that everyone around the world accepted, including Quentin Tarantino, Martin Scorsese, and more who hated superhero films, but now are changed men and women. The music, cinematography, set design, cast, everything and everyone on this film is perfect and don’t deserve to go to Heaven, but a place better than Heaven. Thank you Daniel and Jared for creating a modern masterpiece, and keeping the life of Stan “The Morbius” Lee alive. Stan Lee just walked out of his grave, and went to the El Capitan just to watch this, and is now a Morbius connoisseur and collector. By the time this film turns 1 year old, cinema would’ve already changed into different directions, because Morbius made such an impact. So thank you to the Morbheads who made this modern masterpiece, and here’s to more Morbius sequels (which equals more modern masterpieces and changes in cinema).

author: @Praise___YaH
text:
Guys, Here is our Savior

YaH The Heavenly FATHER HIMSELF was Who they Crucified/Pierced for our sins and “HERE IS THE PROOF”

From the Ancient Egyptian Semitic: 
"Yad He Vav He" is what Moshe (Moses) wrote, when Moses asked YaH His Name (Exodus 3)

Ancient Egyptian Semitic Direct Translation
Yad - "Behold The Hand"
He - "Behold the Breath"
Vav - "Behold The NAIL" <— YaH’s Crucifixion
He - "Behold the Breath"

“Behold the HAND that Beholds The NAIL” 

PROVES - YAH The Heavenly Father HIMSELF was Who they Crucified

That is EXACTLY what Moses Wrote

Here is what they mean

YaH's Name:
(Ya)d + (H)e, as YaH is what Moses called Him and YaH Declared: "this is My Name, this is My Name for all generations" (Exodus 3)

YaH is The Creator of “MAN”: (Genesis 2:7)
Yad He, (HAND BREATH), as YaH's "HAND" Formed man from the dust  of the Earth and His "BREATH" made him a living being (Adam)

YaH's Sacrifice of Crucifixion for “MAN”:
Vav He (NAIL BREATH), the "NAIL" through YaH’s "HAND", in Sacrifice of Crucifixion, that whosoever shall call YaH Savior, His “BREATH” brings forth life (Salvation)

How YaH arrives:
YaH arrives via the Tent of Meeting (Exodus 33:7:11, Isaiah 54, 55), where a Tent is erected outside the city, a cloud descends upon the entrance of the Tent and YaH appears...

Why they demanded YaH to be Crucified:
YaH was Crucified according to Hebrew law (Deuteronomy 21), to be NAILED/PIERCED on an Almond Tree for BLASPHEMY as it was for His NAME they demanded Him Crucified. The Messiah claimed He was YaH...

HE WAS YaH!!!

HalleluYAH translates “Praise ye YaH”

The Hebrew Book of Isaiah

Isaiah 42:8
"I am YaH; that is my Name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols.

Isaiah 43:11
I, I am YAH, and there is no other Savior but Me.

Isaiah 45:5
I am YaH, and there is none else.

author: @Post_Stall_Maneuver
text: Because it was the entire premise of the movie. It wasn't really "it was all a dream," we knoe that, it was "will the team, especially Cobb, make it out of the dream?" He's gone down past the three original layered dreams, one for resuscitation of the original target/facing Mal, and one to save Saito from Limbo (i think) to uphold the arrangement. It was more a matter of if Cobb would make it back out, considering the sedatives, which makes Inception all the better.

author: @diegoh1458
text:
@danielhamilton351 not the way I saw it. if you think ab the state of limbo. the only way Cobb and mal got out of it originally was because they killed themselves after he planted the idea in mals head. in Saitos case we can tell he'd been down there awhile by his aged looks, meaning the sedative was close to wearing off in the real world, further proved by the point that after they take their lives, there's only 20 mins before they land after a 10 ish hour flight. The main thing for me though that proves they weren't lost in limbo at the end, is the movie itself. The whole time we're reminded of Cobbs great "sin" and guilt by planting thr idea in mal's head that gets them out of the limbo state but gets her killed. That fact alone we know makes Cobbs reality actual reality. At the end of the movie Cobb goes to find Saito in limbo. This time though Cobb's aware of how difficult it might be to not only get Saito out, but to get him out without ruining him. He does this by reminding saito to not be an old man filled with regret and waiting to die alone, but to be young men together again which is a beautiful call back to the beginning, but is also the idea that convinces saito to comeback to reality.

long story short Cobb learned from his past of what not to do based off prior experience that enabled him to succeed with bringing saito back. Reoccurring theme actually. him succeeding in itself is how we know he gets out cause he failed countless times in general. I dare say his guilt keeps him grounded or is like a totem for him too. Also Michael cane  said that whenever he's on scene is when Cobb is experiencing reality.  just a couple reasons why I think he actally made it back to his family

author: @naijainnit
text:
Addressing the audience at the screening, Caine explained, via Time:

"When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it, and I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is. I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’ He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene it’s reality.’ So, get that — if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

author: @SultanOxford
text:
The ending exists in the real world. You can hear the spinning totem about to topple off in the end credits

If we were to assume that the ending was in the dream world, then the totem will have kept spinning indefinately.  The character would have eventually spotted that after meeting his children and realized it was a dream. Then taken steps to come out of the dream. 

Nevertheless,  an impressive film with an ending that makes you think what is real or a dream.. and do we even care if it gives us what we want

author: @naveengoyal5243
text:
The below article will help you guys.

According to NME, Caine appeared at a recent screening of the 2010 sci-fi classic.

The 85-year-old said: “When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it.

“And I said to him, ‘I don’t understand where the dream is.’

“I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’

“He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene it’s reality.’ So, get that — if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

Taking this on board the final shots of Inception saw Caine’s Miles pick up Cobb at the airport before taking him home to his children.

So surely this means it was reality and the spinning top was about to drop?

If anything the fact that it was starting to shake surely confirms this since it didn’t wobble when Cobb was actually in a dream.

Back in 2015 Nolan himself gave a cryptic answer to the question that’s been bugging fans for almost a decade.

author: @JTVH2007
text: The ending with the top isn’t even the most emotional moment for me. It’s when he’s walking through the airport showing all the side characters. There isn’t any heart felt goodbyes or even a nod to Arthur or Eames. You just see them look at each other in a split second. And then finally Fisher sees Cobb and it seems like he recognizes him. I’d like to think he realizes in that moment who he is, but decides that it doesn’t matter, and that what comes in the future is more important. Side note: What I would do to just see Michael Caine waving at me at an airport waiting for me to come home… that man is amazing.

author: @andrewmiller3055
text: re the team, I think they all recognized they pulled off an impossible mission, and that in some sense it was not just for their own experience but also for Cobb, so that he could go home.  They are proud of Cobb.  Also they probably didn't want to tip off Fischer - there's a reason for the muted celebration.  I get the sense these teams are freelance anyhows, so once a mission is accomplished it's on to the next one - they go home, lay low, then go wherever it's needed.  Still extraordinary to see a normal moment take on such gravity.  Same with the final scene in Dark Knight Rises etc third film for Batman trilogy for Nolan.  Endings where fairly normal moments take center stage.

author: @beafrancescabufi3953
text:
Yup. There’s a reason for the muted celebration. They didn’t want to tip off Fischer, remember, this guy knows about Inception. He’s trained to defend himself from it, it was already a miracle in itself   that they were able to pull this off. 

Another reason would probably be because they literally just pulled off a crime. They drugged Fischer and dragged him into a shared dream without his consent. Sure, they shared some knowing glances, but in their minds they knew they had to ignore each other and go on with business as usual so as not to get caught. But yeah, it was pretty visible that they were proud of what they did. 

You know how you share that look with your friend after you cheat on a test? That shared look of conspiracy, smirk of confidence and disbelief that you two were able to pull that off? That’s kinda what’s up here.

I love how Arthur gives Cobb a ghost of a nod at 1:55 It was almost as if he was mentally telling Cobb “ You’re free. We did it, I have no regrets. See you soon, brother.”

author: @NapstaMeme
text:
"One day, a man dreamt he was a butterfly.
But when he woke up, the man wasn't sure whether it was a dream or if he really was a butterfly, who was now dreaming that he [is] a man?
isn't it fascinating? 
Those who have dreams are forced to either accept them or let [them] go.
Perhaps a dream held such weight that the dreamer themself lost sight of reality.
Would they then consider reality a dream? 
And what if someone -who- has many dreams, each with their own characteristics?
Which of those dreams is reality to them? I wish I could be there to find out" (Teppei). The quote was from Echidna - However, this quote was rephrased through a Youtuber named Echidnut, Link here >>> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9aTUr_3SgzM&t=11m54s .

author: @Praise___YaH
text:
Guys, Here is our Savior

YaH The Heavenly FATHER HIMSELF was Who they Crucified/Pierced for our sins and “HERE IS THE PROOF”

From the Ancient Egyptian Semitic: 
"Yad He Vav He" is what Moshe (Moses) wrote, when Moses asked YaH His Name (Exodus 3)

Ancient Egyptian Semitic Direct Translation
Yad - "Behold The Hand"
He - "Behold the Breath"
Vav - "Behold The NAIL" <— YaH’s Crucifixion
He - "Behold the Breath"

“Behold the HAND that Beholds The NAIL” 

PROVES - YAH The Heavenly Father HIMSELF was Who they Crucified

That is EXACTLY what Moses Wrote

Here is what they mean

YaH's Name:
(Ya)d + (H)e, as YaH is what Moses called Him and YaH Declared: "this is My Name, this is My Name for all generations" (Exodus 3)

YaH is The Creator of “MAN”: (Genesis 2:7)
Yad He, (HAND BREATH), as YaH's "HAND" Formed man from the dust  of the Earth and His "BREATH" made him a living being (Adam)

YaH's Sacrifice of Crucifixion for “MAN”:
Vav He (NAIL BREATH), the "NAIL" through YaH’s "HAND", in Sacrifice of Crucifixion, that whosoever shall call YaH Savior, His “BREATH” brings forth life (Salvation)

How YaH arrives:
YaH arrives via the Tent of Meeting (Exodus 33:7:11, Isaiah 54, 55), where a Tent is erected outside the city, a cloud descends upon the entrance of the Tent and YaH appears...

Why they demanded YaH to be Crucified:
YaH was Crucified according to Hebrew law (Deuteronomy 21), to be NAILED/PIERCED on an Almond Tree for BLASPHEMY as it was for His NAME they demanded Him Crucified. The Messiah claimed He was YaH...

HE WAS YaH!!!

HalleluYAH translates “Praise ye YaH”

The Hebrew Book of Isaiah

Isaiah 42:8
"I am YaH; that is my Name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols.

Isaiah 43:11
I, I am YAH, and there is no other Savior but Me.

Isaiah 45:5
I am YaH, and there is none else.

author: @benfranklinsays2713
text: The concept of Inception was lifted from Total Recall 1990. Arnold went to REKALL paid for an implanted memory of being a secret agent, who killed the bad guys, saved the planet and got the girl. At the end of the movie as  he is kissing Melina. the scene fades to white not black is Houser coming out of the memory he paid for or not??? Ron Shussett and Dan o Bannon came up with the dreamscape adventure 20 years before Nolan. So let's give credit were it's due first. They also wrote script for Alien 1979. Inception is a very good movie but it's basic premise was copied from Philip K. Dicks' "We Can Remember it for you Wholesale."

author: @audi88
text: Well after 10 years I think my opinion has changed and I think the ending is still a dream, because he doesnt remember the drive back home or how things have changed around. He simply recalls the convinient changes to his former memories as it happens in a progressive dream,but he doesn't care anymore and hence let goes of the spinning top. In any case its a brave acceptance of fate and reality by our hero. Hence whether its a dream or not doesn't matter to him anymore.

author: @mcbillygoat
text: Allow me to be judge, jury and executioner for this question. My view is that it is reality. For the most part it is because of what Michael Caine said but more so because the children act out in a very personal way that doesn’t seem distant nor ethereal. Also, when the kid says, “We’re building a house on a cliff,” well that can be chalked up to ‘kids say the darndest things’ even tho they are known to make sand castles etc. While all this is compelling information, the way it is shot lends it to be open for interpretation and one could argue that it could be a dream regardless, nobody can definitely say it’s one or the other in the abstract. It’s almost the optimist vs the pessimist debate. The romantic vs the disenchanted. And why is Elliot Page in a dress?

author: @Praise___YaH
text:
Guys, Here is our Savior

YaH The Heavenly FATHER HIMSELF was Who they Crucified/Pierced for our sins and “HERE IS THE PROOF”

From the Ancient Egyptian Semitic: 
"Yad He Vav He" is what Moshe (Moses) wrote, when Moses asked YaH His Name (Exodus 3)

Ancient Egyptian Semitic Direct Translation
Yad - "Behold The Hand"
He - "Behold the Breath"
Vav - "Behold The NAIL" <— YaH’s Crucifixion
He - "Behold the Breath"

“Behold the HAND that Beholds The NAIL” 

PROVES - YAH The Heavenly Father HIMSELF was Who they Crucified

That is EXACTLY what Moses Wrote

Here is what they mean

YaH's Name:
(Ya)d + (H)e, as YaH is what Moses called Him and YaH Declared: "this is My Name, this is My Name for all generations" (Exodus 3)

YaH is The Creator of “MAN”: (Genesis 2:7)
Yad He, (HAND BREATH), as YaH's "HAND" Formed man from the dust  of the Earth and His "BREATH" made him a living being (Adam)

YaH's Sacrifice of Crucifixion for “MAN”:
Vav He (NAIL BREATH), the "NAIL" through YaH’s "HAND", in Sacrifice of Crucifixion, that whosoever shall call YaH Savior, His “BREATH” brings forth life (Salvation)

How YaH arrives:
YaH arrives via the Tent of Meeting (Exodus 33:7:11, Isaiah 54, 55), where a Tent is erected outside the city, a cloud descends upon the entrance of the Tent and YaH appears...

Why they demanded YaH to be Crucified:
YaH was Crucified according to Hebrew law (Deuteronomy 21), to be NAILED/PIERCED on an Almond Tree for BLASPHEMY as it was for His NAME they demanded Him Crucified. The Messiah claimed He was YaH...

HE WAS YaH!!!

HalleluYAH translates “Praise ye YaH”

The Hebrew Book of Isaiah

Isaiah 42:8
"I am YaH; that is my Name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols.

Isaiah 43:11
I, I am YAH, and there is no other Savior but Me.

Isaiah 45:5
I am YaH, and there is none else.

צריך להיות מהנדס חכם כדי להנדס את משקל האבנים שסחבנו במצריים בצורה זווית שונה מלווה בתוספות,
אך אך
השיעבוד סביב  שעות מרובות כמו 12 שעות, ללא לקום שעה מלפני ועוד נסיעות ועוד שינה....בסוף אתה סמרטוט של העשירים....כלומר מגיע לפנסיה וזהו...
פה נגמר ואינם מבינים עומק הדבר כי הריי מעל 90 אחוז לקח מחיי האדם....לצורך כסף חברים
כסף, וכי תורת שה כולה סובבת סביב זכויות האדם
כולל למוסלמים ולנוצרים...הריי נוח נתן סוג של תפוס היתנהגות....
לא מוזר שיכלנו לקבל את התורה בעוד מיליון ואחד דרכים וויותר הגיוני לקבל נניח בשעה שהכול מסודר  ...
והריי כן כי כבר הכול מסודר  ועל זה מוסיף עוד..
במלחמה על זכויות חופש האדם מלחמת אמת התנהלה שם אם משה ואהרון וציפורה ועוד מיני רבים...
שם דווקא קיבלנו את כול התורה....לא מוזר...
ועניין מדעי...לאחריי זה..מורכב.....אבל החכם בדעתו ישראל מתוך כול הדרכים והאפשריות לקבל את התורה ואף עדיף בשלב שהכול מסודר כך משלש משמחתו,
ונאמר יין משמח לבב אנוש.
מתוך כול הדרכים והאפשריות קיבלנו אותה על מלחמה על זכויות האדם....שעות מרובות של עבודה אם לחץ מטורף,  אשר מעין והגיע לגינהום ונאמר לו פה זה סטטיסטיקה....כימעט בתוך אתה עבד....ממש עבד 
זה לא סרט ומציאות קיימת לחלוטין ולא תיאוריה...
אבל בדור הזה יש תוספות מעל או מעבר
בעשור האחרון, מדובר ל היתנהגות של חיות
ונאמר בסוד כן...אמיתי...נאמר
כבהמות אוכלות חציר,
כלומר דיבור מלוכלך...בקטע פוגעני משולב.
צחוקים שטויות שנובעים מאנשים מתורבתים, ומושכלים וחכמים...יש לזה ריח שונה לגמריי
זה מגילה ארוכה
שלא נדע השומרים בפתח הא3מון ומגילת אסתר 
בידם..ומצודה פרוסה
כול זה תוספות על גבי השגרה השוחקת, מלווה בלחץ וחוקים נוקשים מהונדס כראוי כי שוקל הייטב
לפי המשקל הינך יודע את ההינדוס
כמה נפלו וכמה הגיעו ותהנו איפה הם מה קורה פה לאם אני הולך
הגונגל...
ואיך מלאך השלום אומר ברמז אני עליון כי אין שלום בתחתונים לא בחיות ולא באדם
שוק
רבי עקיבא היה אומר
טיפה ועוד טיפה בסוף עושה חור באבן
טיפה זה לא אשליות....זה אמת מטפטפת, 
אשלייה לא תעשה חור באבן

הדתי ראה שהביאו בעל ו5ישה זוג נכים על כיסא גלגלים ועשו מי הם צחוק, לא רק לא רק...
אהרון הבין בדיוק מה הנאציים רמזו לו בישראל...

ואמר אסור לצפות בדברים כאלו...

שלא יתפלאו אמר הדתי אם הנשים שלהם יגיעו לכיסא גלגלים...

author: @Velvety_Lantern
text: I really don't understand how people think he is not dreaming. Like the children are sitting at the exact same place, with the exact same clothes, the exact same lighting is there. The childeren have not aged while cobb has been away for long. Even though time moves slower in dreams it still should have been a while because he was working and shit. It would never in a million years be possible in reality that the time he sees them again will be extremely similar to his memory of the last time he saw them. It's only because it's not real. His brain can only contruct this image of his children because this was how he saw them the last time. He just doesn't know it because he went through all this. And he is finally with his children. He is actually the one stuck in the dreamscape and not his wife. I don't understand anyone who thinks otherwise. But try to convince me

author: @mosesmosa2563
text:
והדתי גם אמר שלא יקחו קשה..אנחנו נקיים כמו שמיכה לבנה.....והדגיש
מי חזר בתשובה ומכפר על מעשיו ואם תשובתו אמת
אז כן..ולפעמים תלוי גובהה החטאין
כן כן יש מעשים שהשם לא סולח...
ורמוז
כול תפילת 18
שארית עימך והתמימים והחנונים והטובים...
וצדיקים מכול השבטים...כגון חרידים...חבד..נחמן...
הריי רובם דרך ארץ זה אבני יסוד..
ורובם הנסתרות שלהם זה דרך ארץ...
לא סודות כמו ספירות...עולמות...ומדע והכול מדוד ובדוק כלבנה שבונה חומה..אמת=חומה
אלא הנסתרות שלהם זה דרך ארץ
רמת תרבות שאין לתאר....והילדים כנל,
ופה נאמר איפה נפלו גיבוריים...
בעל הסולם...סודותיו היו בעינייני דרך ארץ....
והריי תידע זאת...ומצודה פרוסה וכול מעשיהם נכתבים
בספר החיים, 
כלומר יש כתמים השם שלא נדע,

לכן נאמר שארית עימך...כול תפילת 18 קוראים אנו זאת...
כרגע זה עניין רוחני אך רוב העומק..יכול להימדד מדעית...
אין שום ניגוד

אותם אנשים בדרך ארץ נקראים ונאמן בכול ביתי הוא.

ואנשים ישר רצים ורוצים לקפוץ בדגית הים..
ושלא נדע בחדר החיות לא מעט מוחות ענקיי היסטוריה נפלו כנוצה,
לצד איזה חייה תעמוד?
חדר החיות יצאו מימנו מעורפלים והעירפול מיתחזק מיום ליום..מבוך

אנחנו לא רצחנו כלכלית כמות יהודיים מטורפת,
ועוד שם....
אצלינו הכול תקין....
זה ההם שם תשאלו אותם מה קרה פה בעשור האחרון...

שיעבוד רצחני מלווה במשמעת של גטו, בתוספות של מלחמות ואי אימון, ועוד

מי שרוצה שישאר בצד ההוא...
אבל הטובים יוצאים מי שם

היו אנשים במוסד השבק שהגיעו לאן הגיעו 
במכונת אמת חחחח
בסוף  קרה מה קרה שם

והינה שער

text:

text:

מספר 1 וישארו לנצח...בעוד דורות רבים מילים אלו כגון יסוד העומד עולמים
