author: @jillum89
text:
Archer ​ "you wake up in real life in which your memories in the dreamscape are quickly faded away and erased and your current conscious state will reconnect with the mental state before falling asleep in the first place"
I'm sure that this is true in real life. I think you're right about the real world. But movies often play by different rules - their rules - and not necessarily the rules we have in real life. We have to apply the rules of the movie to the universe of the movie when we interpret what's going on in the movie. And what you describe doesn't appear to be the nature of the movie-universe. 


Mal saw things and experienced things in her dreams ... and she was in limbo for decades too. And when she woke up, all of it was still in her. After waking, she still remembered the belief that the world isn't real - a belief that she gained in the dream. She wasn't convinced of that when she went to sleep. But she continuously believed it to be completely real years and years after.
The entire plot about the movie ... going into Fisher's mind to plant an idea that's going to stick with him ... that's also would make no sense if it was an in-universe mechanic that he was just going to wake up and just forget it all immediately.


It does appear that the in universe lore of dreaming is that it kinda sticks after waking up. Like one continued stream.


And for that reason, I wondered too ... how can one remember a phone number by heart after decades in limbo? :)

author: @theantiliberal-l5p
text: Archer But, in this movie the dreams doesn't work like the drugs in the real world, in reality, of course yes dreams faded and so does the memory. But the machine that cobb used is unreal, it has the ability to connect two people consciousness. And judging from cobb's trip to the limbo, he seemed to remember everything, the points he brings up in the movie about limbo is very jumpy, the beginning of the limbo, the middle of the limbo where he planted the idea inside his wife's head, and the end of the limbo. And that's when he told ariadne his story, that was years after his trip to the limbo. The limbo isn't something like a normal dream, where you wake up and the memory fades. The point of limbo is you fell into limitless consciousness, a dream land, It's unlike any normal dream. And the effect of the device also is more than just put you into a sleeping state where you are lucid dreaming, it's a lifelike feeling, you felt every second and you can remember them after you woke up. Real life lucid dreams doesn't work like that, you can feel it when you are in it, but when you woke up you only remember points of the dream. We can't take real life science into a sci-fi movie. The device was made for military usage for them training in a life simulation. So i do think it's kind of a plothole where saito just woke up from living an old life and being able to remember the phone call.

author: @wodkah
text:
@VLVLArtthe experience when waking up is just something else, you can’t describe it. You only know if you experienced it yourself. And I, too, had a similar experience after smoking some weird stuff. It’s like a lifetime just vanishes and during the wake up process you think to yourself, „wtf was this not real? am I really back in this life?“. 

The tought process is just so trippy, it’s just not describable.

Also, before experiencing this other life I was in the void this one time. There was nothing and I was convinced that this was the real life in the void. During this time in this nothingness, I tought to myself „this can’t be it? I remember other things, I remember different objects, am I dreaming?“ 

And you try to wake up but you can’t. You stay in this void for as long as the stuff you smoked wants you to stay there. Then after what felt were days I finally started to manifest objects to interact with.

An eerie experience, on the one hand I‘d like to experience it again, on the other hand not so much

author: @caleblim6890
text: Here's the way I always saw it: whenever it was a dream, after the first few seconds the top never wobbled. Watch the top closely, and you can clearly see it shaking, slowing down. Just before the cut, you can catch an obvious shake. That means it's slowing down, thus he isn't dreaming. I caught that first time, and whenever I watch this scene back I get more convinced that Cobb is in fact in the real world.

author: @AbhishekKumar50
text:
Reasons why Cobb is not in a dream -
1. The Ring. Someone pointed out he's wearing a ring whilst in a dream and doesn't when he's not. He's not wearing one in the final scene. BOOM! Not a dream.
2. You clearly see the totem slowing down and about to topple. Even if the scene is cut it's understood that the totem slowed down hence it will topple!
3. Michael Cane revealed in an interview that all scenes with him in it are absolutely real. Nowhere does he appear in a dream. Source: https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/michael-caine-inception-christopher-nolan-ending-real-dream-leonardo-dicaprio-a8488286.html


So guys it's not a dream, its understood. Inception is a confusing film but while I was watching it the around the 4th time I got it, still if you have some reason to believe its a dream sequence we can discuss it :-)

author: @bradleyrudland321
text: There have been cinematic masterpieces such as Terminator 2, The Matrix, Lost Highway, Existence, Clockwork Orange, Fight Club and countless other films that are either thought provoking or visual benchmarks. Inception would have to be the one film that is succinct and cohesive, has multiple layers and is visually spectacular. I believe that there are 4 separate plots in which Nolan has perfectly seamed into one story. If you miss any part of the dialogue in this film then it will make no sense, it took me about 5 viewings to understand the concept of Cobb making Inception a reality and his battle to finally erase the memory of his wife to succeed in the one goal in his life which is to see his children again. Nolan is on the same level if not higher than visionary director/writers like Cronenberg, Kubrick, Lynch, Wakowski Brothers and Snyder.

author: @LorenHelgeson
text: I suffered from sepsis two years ago. Waking up from a 12 hour coma, I forgot EVERYTHING. Some things were retained, others were not. Having seen this movie in theaters four times, renting it in DVD and on Blu-Ray, and buying it on CD sountrack, I was all about this movie. All of that said, I remember NOTHING about the movie. One consolation is I get to experience new stuff like this all over again, seeing them as if I never watched them before. Lost my collection, though, so I have no means of watching it again any time soon. I don't care to watch online movies. I am quite entitled to, but I have no interest. It's on my list of stuff to add back into my collection again.

author: @rising.cinema
text: @LorenHelgeson Sorry to hear about those challenges… but deeply encouraged by your positive attitude. Hope you can relive movies and stories in a healing + inspiring way ❤

author: @LorenHelgeson
text: ​​@rising.cinemathank you very much. Fighting the good fight as best I can. Every day, I am remembering new things, and eventually it'll catch up soon enough that I can return back to square one.

author: @TheKickboxnico
text:
Michael Caine explained the ending of Inception

SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER

After more than eight years of debate over the ending of Inception, Michael Caine has offered some clarity on the movie’s mysterious final moments.

While speaking at a Film 4 Summer Screen showing of Christopher Nolan’s acclaimed thriller, Caine—who played the father of Leonardo DiCaprio’s Dom Cobb—shared some insider knowledge on whether Cobb was awake or dreaming in Inception‘s closing sequence.

“When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it,” Caine said. “And I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is.’ I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’ He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene, it’s reality.’ So get that — if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

There you have it, Inception fans. Since Caine is in the final scene, it’s reality. Case closed. The totem falls.

http://time.com/5368056/michael-caine-inception-ending/

author: @SuperGeronimo999
text:
But the thing is, this isn't his totem, it belongs to his wife... and if anyone else touches it, it loses its power. So, it can't tell you if its a dream or not. Cobb's totem is never revealed in the movie, but he always wears his wedding ring in his dreams (because in dreams he is still united with his wife) but in reality he doesn't wear it.

In the ending he doesn't wear the ring.

author: @SuperGeronimo999
text:
It's a great ending, because it makes you wonder... the totem actually isn't important. It belongs to his wife, and not to him. If anyone else touches it, it doesn't work anymore. So, even if it was a dream, it would stop spinning, and you can see it become slower and almost falling towards the end. 

Now, Cobb's totem has never been revealed, but its probably his wedding ring. He always wears it, in his dreams (where his wife still exists), but not in the reality. And in the ending he doesn't wear it either.

author: @joeshmoe3203
text: Notice that he spins the false totem, as if to say reality is in the eyes of perception. The dreams each one of us have are this false totem of mere perception. The reality we face is the one we must accept individually and accountable. Where the lines blur between dream and reality is the subject of inception. Cobb knows his reality, but inadvertently performs inception on himself and consequently the audience.

author: @esmiq7771
text: I had dreams of a son I never had.  I wrote about him in a journal so I could remember every detail while it was fresh and I told him how much I love him. His sweet face how I miss it. When I find out I was expecting we called our baby by his name just like the dream but turned out she was a girl. I literally could not believe it and to this day I wonder if in some reality he remembers me too. He was to real, I dreamt of him over and over for months that I'd wake up looking for my baby when I wasn't even a mother yet. Will my son ever come home? But I doubt I'll ever have another. Things in my life changed, outlook, career so I get really sad sometimes.

author: @zodd1790
text:
@grandoldsoul4691 A Parallel Life / Awoken By A Lamp

throw away account cause this is really personal.

My last semester at a certain college I was assulted by a football player for walking where he was trying to drive (note he was 325lbs I was 120lbs), while unconscious on the ground I lived a different life.

I met a wonderful young lady, she made my heart skip and my face red, I pursued her for months and dispatched a few jerk boyfriends before I finally won her over, after two years we got married and almost immediately she bore me a daughter.

I had a great job and my wife didn't have to work outside of the house, when my daughter was two she [my wife] bore me a son. My son was the joy of my life, I would walk into his room every morning before I left for work and doted on him and my daughter.

One day while sitting on the couch I noticed that the perspective of the lamp was odd, like inverted. It was still in 3D but... just.. wrong. (It was a square lamp base, red with gold trim on 4 legs and a white square shade). I was transfixed, I couldn't look away from it. I stayed up all night staring at it, the next morning I didn't go to work, something was just not right about that lamp.

I stopped eating, I left the couch only to use the bathroom at first, soon I stopped that too as I wasn't eating or drinking. I stared at the fucking lamp for 3 days before my wife got really worried, she had someone come and try to talk to me, by this time my cognizance was breaking up and my wife was freaking out. She took the kids to her mother's house just before I had my epiphany.... the lamp is not real.... the house is not real, my wife, my kids... none of that is real... the last 10 years of my life are not fucking real!

The lamp started to grow wider and deeper, it was still inverted dimensions, it took up my entire perspective and all I could see was red, I heard voices, screams, all kinds of weird noises and I became aware of pain.... a fucking shit ton of pain... the first words I said were "I'm missing teeth" and opened my eyes. I was laying on my back on the sidewalk surrounded by people that I didn't know, lots were freaking out, I was completely confused.

At some point a cop scooped me up, dragged/walked me across the sidewalk and grass and threw me face down in the back of a cop car, I was still confused.

I was taken to the hospital by the cop (seems he didn't want to wait for the ambulance to arrive) and give CT scans and shit..

I went through about 3 years of horrid depression, I was grieving the loss of my wife and children and dealing with the knowledge that they never existed, I was scared that I was going insane as I would cry myself to sleep hoping I would see her in my dreams. I never have, but sometimes I see my son, usually just a glimpse out of my peripheral vision, he is perpetually 5 years old and I can never hear what he says.

EDIT (24 hours after post): never though anyone would read this, I changed a line so that it no longer seems that my 2 year old daughter bore a child.

I have never seen Inception or the Star Trek episode so many have mentioned (but I will eventually)

author: @Praise___YaH
text:
Guys, Here is our Savior

YaH The Heavenly FATHER HIMSELF was Who they Crucified/Pierced for our sins and “HERE IS THE PROOF”

From the Ancient Egyptian Semitic: 
"Yad He Vav He" is what Moshe (Moses) wrote, when Moses asked YaH His Name (Exodus 3)

Ancient Egyptian Semitic Direct Translation
Yad - "Behold The Hand"
He - "Behold the Breath"
Vav - "Behold The NAIL" <— YaH’s Crucifixion
He - "Behold the Breath"

“Behold the HAND that Beholds The NAIL” 

PROVES - YAH The Heavenly Father HIMSELF was Who they Crucified

That is EXACTLY what Moses Wrote

Here is what they mean

YaH's Name:
(Ya)d + (H)e, as YaH is what Moses called Him and YaH Declared: "this is My Name, this is My Name for all generations" (Exodus 3)

YaH is The Creator of “MAN”: (Genesis 2:7)
Yad He, (HAND BREATH), as YaH's "HAND" Formed man from the dust  of the Earth and His "BREATH" made him a living being (Adam)

YaH's Sacrifice of Crucifixion for “MAN”:
Vav He (NAIL BREATH), the "NAIL" through YaH’s "HAND", in Sacrifice of Crucifixion, that whosoever shall call YaH Savior, His “BREATH” brings forth life (Salvation)

How YaH arrives:
YaH arrives via the Tent of Meeting (Exodus 33:7:11, Isaiah 54, 55), where a Tent is erected outside the city, a cloud descends upon the entrance of the Tent and YaH appears...

Why they demanded YaH to be Crucified:
YaH was Crucified according to Hebrew law (Deuteronomy 21), to be NAILED/PIERCED on an Almond Tree for BLASPHEMY as it was for His NAME they demanded Him Crucified. The Messiah claimed He was YaH...

HE WAS YaH!!!

HalleluYAH translates “Praise ye YaH”

The Hebrew Book of Isaiah

Isaiah 42:8
"I am YaH; that is my Name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols.

Isaiah 43:11
I, I am YAH, and there is no other Savior but Me.

Isaiah 45:5
I am YaH, and there is none else.

author: @nanabaakanagyiriwah1876
text:
The whole thing was a dream. Show me an international airport in the US that has a grassy playground right outside of arrivals. Those airports are  like little cities.  No way you gonna see grass and trees. Flying International you have to go thru long lines at customs, you just don't get off you flight, walk quickly thru customs and out a door to an eating area right there, you have to navigate a great distance to get out of the arrivals area. To me, this showed he was still dreaming. Not to mention that is Mal's spinning top, not his.
When this movie first came out, I read so many comments in the comment sections on the internet I was cross-eyed. Then one day years later it hit me. The entire movie was a dream he never woke up from, to the very end.

author: @BC-qw6jj
text: I was visiting my parents in my early 20s and slept on the couch. The next morning, I met the love of my life, had a child with her and grew old. I outlived my wife. I went to sleep on Christmas eve...and woke up on my parents' couch. Again in my 20s. Woke up with the most severe sense of loss and wept. This 2nd lifetime is harder. Never married. I'm 50 again as I write this. Money is tight. Had abusive relationships. I drink alcohol everyday. Now when I sleep. I hope to find myself with my wife and daughter again. Not sure what happened to me or why. Parallel universe? A consciousness switch with another me? I may never know. But I will never forget the love that was gifted to me.

author: @sagarock5528
text:
For anyone who want to understand the ending: after watching this movie a lot of times over the years and looking at every detail i can tell you Cobb isnt dreaming and here is why

In the first few scenes where Cobb and Arthur were inside saitos dream, (second dream)Cobb shot Arthur so hé can wake up in the first dream ( hé didnt go to a limbo) plus he returned  and Cobb to the real world. So the limbo thing is just and illusion, an inception an idea that Cobb and his team gave to saito when he got shot in fisher's dream so he would stay with them and not return to the real world and be see that Cobb mission is done and the arrangement is successfull.Cobb did inception to saito just like he did to mal when he convinced her she was dreaming...at the end we see Cobb trying to re convince saito that he was dreaming and the limbo is just an illusion, so he reached his gun killed cobb and killed himself to comeback to the real world. + at the end Cobb for thé first time he could see his childrens faces when he was dreaming hecould only see their backs + the if you look closely at the spinning thing at the end you can see it started to unbalance.

author: @masoodvoon8999
text: What makes his movies so great is how Nolan explores various conflicts between subjective and universal truths (and does it with perfect paced suspenseful action with the ending uncertain and with the best cinematography and score of course). I find him to be much like Socrates with his moves the Socratic method. He realizes that everything we see and much of what we think are imperfect projections of reality, but that we must do our best to achieve those universal truths, as it is the only way in the end to bring us forward.

author: @SecondQuantisation
text:
God this film is good. 


Perfectly capturing the way dreams are so deeply personal and yet an experience shared by every single person; the confusion upon waking, the slipping away of memories, the half-remembered details, the growing realisation upon waking...

Then there's the implications; the pride and satisfaction felt by the team, Saito's promise is remembered, the stillness as Cobb walks up to immigration, the shear euphoria at "Welcome home" then seeing his kids and then, finally, the moment where Cobb ignores the totem, which spins... and spins....... and spins.......... and...... [credits]

Alongside a short list of films like American Beauty (Kevin Spacey ignored...), Inception is one of only a handful of films which leave you thinking at the end "Wow". Not because of spectacle (though it has that) but because it is "satisfying". A feeling like you went on a journey of importance and interest and really got to take something away from it.

I wouldn't ever want to see a sequel, it would destroy the singular beauty of Inception, but I hope another film with similar impact and thought provoking themes comes along.

Also , there is a passage in the Holy Scriptures that says mercy triumphs over judgement .  Love people ; forgive them ; show mercy and extend grace.  It's actually healthy.

author: @iWillWakeYouUp
text:
I watched this movie with my then-girlfriend in the cinema. We had no idea what it was about. We heard it's fantastic and I was excited to see it. When we arrived at the cinema, a bunch of my ex gf's friends came up to us, having just come out of a previous showing of the film. They were mindblown and told me they had heart palpitations at the end because it was so anxiety producing and riveting. I thought they were silly girls.
Went in at when all the dream levels came together at the end, I was almost having an anxiety attack lol. I remember being so ridiculously immersed and invested in the film that I had a physical reaction to it. Coming out of it, I reacted exactly the same as the girls did when I stumbled across a friend of mine.

Inception has been criticized and added to meme-culture over the years because it (rightfully) became very popular, but that popularity doesn't negate the greatness of this film. Watching it in the cinema for the first time, knowing nothing about it, was an experience I will never forget.

author: @TheKickboxnico
text:
Michael Caine explained the ending of Inception

SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER

After more than eight years of debate over the ending of Inception, Michael Caine has offered some clarity on the movie’s mysterious final moments.

While speaking at a Film 4 Summer Screen showing of Christopher Nolan’s acclaimed thriller, Caine—who played the father of Leonardo DiCaprio’s Dom Cobb—shared some insider knowledge on whether Cobb was awake or dreaming in Inception‘s closing sequence.

“When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it,” Caine said. “And I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is.’ I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’ He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene, it’s reality.’ So get that — if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

There you have it, Inception fans. Since Caine is in the final scene, it’s reality. Case closed. The totem falls.

http://time.com/5368056/michael-caine-inception-ending/

author: @cobes11
text:
Not really. Anyone who has heavily used hallucinagens heavily knows all these feelings well. Feelings like constantly doubting reality and not knowing if the world you are in is the real one or just another trip where you got stuck. The first few times on such drugs where they seem to last for weeks or months and make you panic that you are stuck there forever so you should just learn to live in this new word.... I remember those. The friends you make with your "projections" become the closest ones of your life. When you finally try to seek sobriety, the heartbreak and loneliness that comes from having to say goodbye to them is like a part of you dying. 

I have never been the same emotionally.

author: @lucasseverin4524
text:
Michael Caine revealed the secret about the ending in this Interview :  http://time.com/5368056/michael-caine-inception-ending/

“When I got the script of Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it,” Caine said. “And I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is.’ I said, ‘When is it the dream and when is it reality?’ He said, ‘Well, when you’re in the scene, it’s reality.’ So get that — if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.”

text: I love how he is enthralled that this is all really happening.  Then for a moment as he enters his kitchen, it is like he is shaking himself out of a trance, seems to wonder if this is a dream, thinks about the top, and spins it.  Then he forgets about it the moment he sees his children's faces.  DiCaprio does so much with just his expressions in this sequence (all these fine actors do, actually).

author: @stevenwatchorn9816
text:
My favorite Nolan films (Memento, The Prestige, this one) end with a touch of ambiguity between happiness and sadness.  What I love here is how the audience is left to choose which is more important to them:  Cobb's happiness or whether it is real (and I know about the ring  cue, but there is no guarantee this holds here, especially if he is in someone else's dream... or even still in a version of limbo).  There is the crescendo of music, which sounds hopeful, as he sees his children (even if he is wondering a little if it is a dream).  Then the *same* theme is played more quietly to suggest, first, quiet happiness and contentment, and then plays on longer than might be expected, developing the idea that something *may* be a little off (with the disquieting, throbbing hum just below).  And it lets us decide whether we think that is more important or not.  I absolutely love that.

(and I keep coming back to, how did he get himself and Saito out of limbo with no kick?  Unlike every other time, it just happened... or did it?  If he convinced Saito to commit suicide with him, why not show that, and make it look instead like they just came out? into a world where *everything* turned out for the best?)

author: @thelazyalgorithm8164
text:
Everyone with the different interpretations of the movie, you guys are all right!! The whole point to the ending is not just that Cobb decided to let go and move on, but also to give the viewer their own personal interpretations of the ending. 

It's beautiful in a way because in your head the movie can end however you want. But at the same time Nolan slips in so many subtle details, that it makes you question even your own original thought.

 That's the beauty of these types of endings in films, makes it kind of worth the money in theaters as oppose to some bland scene and a credit role.

author: @Praise___YaH
text:
Guys, Here is our Savior

YaH The Heavenly FATHER HIMSELF was Who they Crucified/Pierced for our sins and “HERE IS THE PROOF”

From the Ancient Egyptian Semitic: 
"Yad He Vav He" is what Moshe (Moses) wrote, when Moses asked YaH His Name (Exodus 3)

Ancient Egyptian Semitic Direct Translation
Yad - "Behold The Hand"
He - "Behold the Breath"
Vav - "Behold The NAIL" <— YaH’s Crucifixion
He - "Behold the Breath"

“Behold the HAND that Beholds The NAIL” 

PROVES - YAH The Heavenly Father HIMSELF was Who they Crucified

That is EXACTLY what Moses Wrote

Here is what they mean

YaH's Name:
(Ya)d + (H)e, as YaH is what Moses called Him and YaH Declared: "this is My Name, this is My Name for all generations" (Exodus 3)

YaH is The Creator of “MAN”: (Genesis 2:7)
Yad He, (HAND BREATH), as YaH's "HAND" Formed man from the dust  of the Earth and His "BREATH" made him a living being (Adam)

YaH's Sacrifice of Crucifixion for “MAN”:
Vav He (NAIL BREATH), the "NAIL" through YaH’s "HAND", in Sacrifice of Crucifixion, that whosoever shall call YaH Savior, His “BREATH” brings forth life (Salvation)

How YaH arrives:
YaH arrives via the Tent of Meeting (Exodus 33:7:11, Isaiah 54, 55), where a Tent is erected outside the city, a cloud descends upon the entrance of the Tent and YaH appears...

Why they demanded YaH to be Crucified:
YaH was Crucified according to Hebrew law (Deuteronomy 21), to be NAILED/PIERCED on an Almond Tree for BLASPHEMY as it was for His NAME they demanded Him Crucified. The Messiah claimed He was YaH...

HE WAS YaH!!!

HalleluYAH translates “Praise ye YaH”

The Hebrew Book of Isaiah

Isaiah 42:8
"I am YaH; that is my Name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols.

Isaiah 43:11
I, I am YAH, and there is no other Savior but Me.

Isaiah 45:5
I am YaH, and there is none else.

author: @VelvetSkyye
text:
@kentatakao6863 I mean that’s wrong. Nolan’s whole point was that, to Cobb, it literally did not matter if the totem was spinning infinitely or not. To us it shouldn’t matter either, as his ring was his totem. If he doesn’t have it on, that’s what we need to know. As we can see when he hands the passport to the guard at 1:20, he does not have the ring. Therefore, couple with finally seeing his kids faces and Christopher’s character being present. This is reality, even if it weren’t, seeing his kids was enough for Cobb specifically, so he didn’t care if mal’s totem kept spinning. Seeing his kids never happened in his dream because in real life he never saw them turn around before he fled so there was nothing his subconscious could fill it with so to him, he was in reality when he saw them.

Some of you not getting that the ending is as simple “perspective” doesn’t mean Nolan was exceptionally cunning, it just means some of you are very dumb. Or at the very least are very unperceptive of things

author: @tylerlloyd83
text: People misinterpret this to mean it doesn’t matter what’s real, since Cobb is happy. But that’s exactly the view Mal was pushing down in Limbo, and Cobb’s rejection of that view is the moral climax of the story. The fact that Cobb isn’t looking at his totem spin is because he is now with his real children, and that reality is so strong and so certain that he doesn’t doubt it, so he doesn’t need the totem anymore.

author: @kant_siddharth_45
@kant_siddharth_45
@splatbubble
text:
@kant_siddharth_45 I appreciate all this.  However, I recall when I fall asleep and dream.. random people show up in my dreams and just talk.  Then when I wake up, I get a 'woah' moment when I see them, like "'hey wow you were in my dream."   And, if I was asleep on a comfy plane, or maybe I had my mouth open when I slept, there is a good chance that someone next to me will give me a goofy smile (Arthur.)    And I've seen people on planes (or trains) wake up, look around all confused, and then immediately call someone.   All the behavior in this final scene is consistent with "bunch of people waking up on a plane."

Although the movie has a very straight plot, and I don't think anyone has ever corroborated my assessment, there is absolutely nothing in this scene that debunks my theory.  ;)  Thank you.

text:
@TRIBOY16 
He knows, And I know on first viewing, at the start of this clip. Nolan said there's a definite answer, it won't be honest storytelling if it didn't. It's just that it shouldn't matter. It's obvious to me. Whenever they woke up, they know how they got there, and transition edit is smooth. Whenever they sunk deeper, there is a brief moment of confusion on how they got there and edit is abrupt without transition. It's obvious he sank deeper. And Cobb probably knew he sank deeper. There's even a scene of Cobb asking that girl if she could remember how they ended up at that cafe when she first sank.

author: @martinbrando1924
text: “When I got the script for Inception, I was a bit puzzled by it," Michael Caine said. "I said to [Nolan], ‘I don’t understand where the dream is. When is it the dream and when is it reality?'” "[Nolan] said, ‘Well, when YOU'RE in a scene, it’s reality.’" Michael Caine said. "So, get that— if I’m in it, it’s reality. If I’m not in it, it’s a dream.” And while Caine, who plays DiCaprio's mentor and father-in-law in the film, is not present in a TON of scenes, he IS present in the one that truly matters: Thus, going on the logic presented by Nolan, because Caine's character is present in the ending sequence, the ending is NOT a dream. DiCaprio's character DID make it home to his children for real!

author: @sociobiologist5141
text:
@BurninPhoenix That's beside the point. I was responding to the callous suggestion that it didn't matter whether it was reality or not, so long as he was happy.


Incidentally, I have read that there is some argument about whether the spinning top was actually his totem. Apparently, the top belonged to his wife, and his totem was his wedding ring.

author: @BurninPhoenix
text: @sociobiologist5141 Though her Totem did its job anyway. It truly showed if they were in a dream or reality even though it was used by Cobb. And his ring was a key factor in the movie as you told which may make it his totem as, it appeared and disappeared based on whether he was in a dream or not.   Though the spinning top was doing its job even when it was used by Cobb and he was the thief who enters others dreams. His wife wasn't a thief.  So why should she need one. So probably, it was actually his own Totem which his wife took occasionally. And even Saito uses it effectively to prove that they were in dream( in Limbo, just before old Saito kills cobb and himself).

author: @sociobiologist5141
text: @BurninPhoenix I thought the whole point of a totem was to enable its owner to distinguish between their waking state and when they were dreaming, and that her suicide was the result of her forgetting which was which?

author: @BurninPhoenix
text: Sociobiologist Yes. Of it is to distinguish if they were dreaming or not. But why should a normal person enter someone's dream? Its done by the thieves anyway to steal from others' dreams.

author: @sociobiologist5141
text: @BurninPhoenix As you say. Interesting.

text: La respuesta correcta está frente a nuestros ojos, donde cobb vuelve a la realidad. En primer lugar, mal, no es así, el viejo no era parte de los sueños y todo el entorno era gente nueva. La película es realmente muy complicada, más de lo que debería haber sido. nolan se pasó de la raya con esta película, es muy bueno porque nos hace pensar, pero lo mismo es para un ser humano promedio incluso mayor de 20 años, son muy pocos los que entenderían esta película. La gran pregunta es por qué vuelven al avión donde la vida es real y no están conectados por nada. De la misma manera, los chinos cumplen su promesa, pero cuando murió, él le dijo que haría lo mismo. Si fuera un mundo irreal, me equivocaría con los niños. Dije.

author: @jhonnatansilva1671
text: The correct answer is in front of our eyes, where cobb comes back to reality. First of all, badly it is not, the old man was not part of the dreams and the whole environment was new people. The movie is really very complicated, more than it should have been. nolan went over the line with this movie, is very good because it makes us think, but the same is for an average human being even older than 20 years, there are very few who would understand this movie. The big question is why do they return to the plane where life is real and they are not connected by anything? In the same way, the Chinese keeps his promise, but when he died, he told him that he would do the same. If it were an unreal world, I would be wrong with the children. I said.

text:
Love this movie and ending.  
My take is he is in reality:
1) He's not wearing his ring.  He only wore the ring in the dream sequences.
2) His kids have aged.  Check the credits.  They are played by older actors at the end and are wearing different clothes.
3) His Father is there.  He was never in any of the dream sequences.

author: @MrMitras18
text: Am I awake? Since when am I awake? How do I know that I am awake? Before waking up did I know that I was not awake? Where was I before I woke up? Where was I after I fell asleep? Where was I when I was dreaming? Where was I when I was asleep and not dreaming? When did I wake up for the first time? Where was I before that? When did I fall asleep for the first time? And where was I before that? Who was I after I fell asleep? Who was I before I woke up? Who was I when I was dreaming? Who was I when I was neither awake nor dreaming? And who in me dreams dreams? Do I know him? How well do I know him? Since when do I know him? And since when is he dreaming? Where is he now? Is he still dreaming? Or am I still dreaming?

author: @WYJAFAK2
text:
Wouldn’t a way to know he wasn’t dreaming be to go into a dream and see how many levels it takes you to get to Limbo? They see level 4 is Limbo so if you were already in a dream then it’d only take 3 sleeps for you to get there? Cobbs been there so he’d know if he saw his constructs again. Wouldn’t this also be a good way to convince Mal that they we or weren’t dreaming before she died? 

Alternatively, if Mal was right and she escaped while he’s still dreaming then it’s not such a bad ending cause if it’s real he gets to be with his kids finally and if it’s a dream then at some point he’s gonna wake up. Or he knows it’s not a dream because Mal hasn’t waken him up yet.

author: @marafichios5471
text:
At 0:39 you can see how Arthur looks at Cobb. I think he wanted to say something like: "We did it, together we made this inception and now you can see your children. Even if it doesnt seem that this is the reality, you should know that the dreams and the complexity of the mind is pure creation."
 I also think that everyone was amazed by what they have done, I mean, the way everything changed in that mind, the levels and all the amazing paradoxes were beautiful. That scene doesnt appear here, but in the end, when Cobb realizes that the old man is Saito I just looked at a blank wall and started crying. A brilliant scene was when that father told his son "I was dissappointed...that you tried" and after I saw it I knew, I knew how much I would love this movie. I just cant explain why that scene especially and the one with Saito. Maybe it is because it was a big plot twist or just the way the regizor thaught about it. I have to say that Hans Zimmer is brilliant and the music had me in tears.

author: @benevolentdictator2315
text:
The constant state of psychosis feels so real when you see his face and that draw to hope he is in reality without knowing for certain as he hesitates to not make eye contact with strangers (until he is acknowledged by the 1st customs agent) as he is conditioned to not do so in another person's dream, thereby confirming his uncertainty. All this, while at the same time wishing his 3rd degree derivative could be real to the point of going there knowing its not real. He shows surprise at having children to greet him; that feeling of a minute being decades of perception in the 3rd degree hence a loss of  being able to confirm "reality" as it feels to be a very old memory. I think many of us have had dreams where we realize we are dreaming and think we wake up only to find ourselves in a false reality of another dream...minutes later we awake in reality, with clarity; only minutes have passed from getting a drink of water but it felt like hours. DiCaprio captures that look of uncertainty so well.
Chris Nolan and Hans Zimmer are amazing. If there could be a way to teach and market that process of creation....

author: @zenthepoet.
text:
You have all been incepted by Nolan. Everything up until he wakes up in the plane is a dream. Which is why on the plane he wakes up as you do from a tremendously deep dream. No one acknowledges him as he exists the airport because they are strangers that subconsciously made it into his dream. When you start a dream, you randomly wake up in a random place. Cobb woke up randomly in so called limbo. 

Nolan put the idea in your head to question whether the ending is reality or a dream. When all long it was a dream that he woke up from. He incepted the audience.


Cobbs wife in real life killed herself because she went crazy. He wasn't around to stop her because hes a workaholic. Due to work and travel he regrets not seeing his kids enough. All of those things seeped into his dreams.

author: @JazzGuitarPractice
text:
"Something You Once Knew" This composition is loosely inspired by the movie "Inception" and Hans Zimmers "Time". I had recently seen the movie for my third time (totally worth it) And it, as of all Christopher Nolans work, has a very special atmosphere to it. So when i was writing this music, i was in this special feeling which gave me clues to what harmonies to use. The title is a quote from the movies ending when Cobb, played by Leonardo DiCaprio brings Saito, Played by Ken Watanabe, back from the "Limbo world" and into the real world. Awesome stuff
Here is the music: https://youtu.be/f6D_Go-59PI

And that my dear folks is the essence of great cinema, WONDER.

author: @ryansteele2446
text: Cobb was always at least one level down. He thought Mal killed herself but when she jumped she woke up at the top level to the real world. He even mentions you have to use your own totem to know when you’re dreaming or not. He was using her totem because he found it in her safe. He was telling the story that she locked it away and he found her totem. We are all down at least one level of a dream. When we are awake in the real world we think it’s real life but in fact we are one level down in the real world. Life is but a dream. Our real bodies are in a higher dimension and our consciousness is being projected in the material world.

author: @shakir1998
text:
That totem was definitely falling over, look at it closely at the end. You could see it slowly start to wobble and then just before it cuts off there's one big wobble which indicates it must've fallen 2 seconds after it cut off. If it was a dream it would've been in a perfect spin. 

Also if you think about it, these dreams they went into were created by an architect. So who would design this dream of him meeting his children and for what reason? It could not be Cobb himself or else he would know this is a dream and would've not spun the totem anyway. I think there is more than enough 'proof' or reason to believe that he did in fact return to America to see his kids. Also it's the best ending so would you not want to believe it.

author: @tfpp1
text: Also, not to spoil it for anyone, but here's a simple way to know it's reality. If you're keeping track of being "awake", you'll know that reality is them getting on the plane. Nowhere in the movie are we told that one of the dream levels is going to be all of them asleep on a plane. So, in keeping track of that, everything that happens after they all awake on the plane is reality. "plane" and simple. Who cares about the spinning top. LOL

author: @tfpp1
text: For me, what makes the scene is seeing the kids' faces. Throughout the entire movie we are denied that, on purpose I'm sure. It is (as Cobb says) "Cathartic" when we - as the audience - are finally given that release of positive emotion to know that he made it back home and we get to finally, FINALLY see how adorable those kids really are. I usually get misty-eyed when watching this scene.

author: @moka2647
text: For all who ask if the end was dream or reality .. At the end of "Inception," Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) finally returns home to his kids after spending a long time in the dream world. Cobb carries a little top with him. If the top keeps spinning, that means he is in a dream. If it stops and falls over, that means he is back in reality.    You're welcome 😁

author: @arthurvin2937
text: I have seen this film 5 times. But today I finally got it right. I studied physics and quantum physics for the last 2 years, and it really helped me to understand this ending from the scientific perspective. Here is the truth. If trying to be down to earth then the wheel is clearly going to stop, just by observing its motion and apply simple physics - it's obvious. So, does this mean that he has found his true reality? Not exactly. Here is a complicated part - from quantum physics perspective there are infinite number of realities and only you subconsiously choose which of those will become consiously real for you. Simply said, true objective reality doesn't exist and never existed at all. It becomes your reality once you begin truly believing in it. You are part of simulated world, a dream. To sum up - Leo has not found reality, he just chose to be his reality that moment when he saw his kids faces.

author: @Lam-ph5tn
text:
This ending is perfect for the movie. Just think about it:
If there hadn't been the image of the spinning spin in the end, nobody would've sincerely doubted that Cobb is in his real life.
By not showing us how the spin falls, Nolan planted the thought of Cobb being in a dream into the minds of the watchers.
He literally performed an inception at the end of the movie and we all are falling for it, not getting the thought out of our mind and debating this topic.
Seriously, this man is a genius.

Something else that gives it away that it’s real is that in his dreams, he doesn’t see his children’s faces. In dreams, when you really want something, you’re often on the verge of getting it but you can’t. Here he actually reunites with his kids. It’s real.

author: @a.y.f.s.1236
text: I'm going to say that it was actually a happy ending and he is back in reality.  I was told, when this movie was in theatres, that you could hear the top fall over after the credits finished.  Watching it again now, its clear to me that the top just barely starts to wobble before the film itself goes to black as it makes that slight scratching sound.

author: @Kragatar
text:
I think he's still dreaming for three reasons.
1. The kids are the same age and living the same moment as in his dreams. If it was real, they'd have grown some, and wouldn't be digging in the yard exactly like the dream.
2. The top had already been spinning for an unnaturally long time before the scene ended. 
3. Saito instantly erasing his criminal record, and having his dad there waiting to pick him up, and his old house being exactly as he left it... That seems highly suspicious and dream-like. My guess is that someone is actually pulling an inception on him, and this scene is the moment where the idea sticks.

author: @johnsmithee6660
text:
It was Chris Nolan's dream to be able to direct this movie. He had worked on the script for nearly 10 years. At around the year 2003, he was planning on making Inception, but he found that he didn't have enough experience in making a big budget movie with all of these effects, and this is why he shelved the idea, and started working on Batman Begins.

It was only after Dark Knight had wrapped, that Nolan felt he had sufficient experience and was able assemble the right team around him, to finally start working on his dream project.

author: @emanne7775
text: Why did he spin his wife's totem, why did it work in the dream world, at the beginning of this clip? And why did he use it when he got 'home'? And not his ring. The argument that he never wore his ring except in the dream world is a pretty good argument that he IS in fact awake. But the point really is that at some point you decide to 'take a leap of faith' and trust what brings you peace even if it doesn't make sense logically, I suppose. It can be seen as a comment on spiritual/religious faith, or, isn't it Buddism which teaches that this world, the material world, isn't really 'real'? Love this movie.....

author: @nattyofastora
text:
*****
That is what you believe, and that is perfectly fine. The ending was intentionally cut like that so it keeps ambiguity to the viewer. But there is no right or wrong way to the ending because no one knows.

author: @nattyofastora
text:
*****
No. It's not. Christopher Nolan himself has stated that he left the ending to be open to interpretation on whether Cobb is dreaming or not. And we see the totem wobble but never fall over and it still could possibly regain balance but we never see that because that is the way Chris Nolan shot it. But as I said before there is no right or wrong with this ending, so you can believe that he is not dreaming and that is perfectly fine. But it isn't wrong to believe that he is still dreaming, and that is what makes this ending so good and unique because it doesn't give the audience a straight answer. You need to accept that.

author: @allbottledup9513
text: Because at other points in the movie, his top has faltered but continued to spin anyways, meaning he's dreaming. The top has to actually topple to be reality, not just falter. Besides, the ends not about whether or not it's real. Cob spins to see if it's a dream but when he sees his kids faces, he doesn't care if it's a dream or reality. He spent what felt like over fifty years trying to get back to them, and in the end he just wanted to be happy and see them again. Even though it's supposed to be left up to the viewer to choose whether or not he's still dreaming, it's almost one hundred percent likely as everyone is surprised and he's not wearing his wedding ring. Though it's not pointed out in the film, the Devils in the detail: He always wore his ring when dreaming but never in reality. In the end, he's not wearing his ring. On top of this, he has no way of knowing that everyone would he surprised that's he's back. That is their actual reactions, including Caito's. He is awake.

author: @_ANGST
text:
It is ambiguous because when he focuses on his children and, as a result, fully loses himself in this possible dream-part of his or someone's brain, he loses the bound to his token making himself dropping the evidence of checking it out forever. If he would turn around and take this token, he could never be sure if it was still the same token extracted out of his secret part of memory, or if it became subjected to the dreamworld. His father could touch it before he would check it out again, or maybe this touch isn't even needed to lose the bound to it, but just the change of perception, so DiCaprio fucked himself up because he didn't care at this moment.

Hence, the token losing its spin could symbolize either DiCaprio being in reality, or DiCaprio being in a dream world and slowly losing his power / perception over his token.

author: @Jakeykeywheels17
text: I just watched this, can someone explain how he found the Asian guy? Did he go into the Asian guys limbo? How did that make them wake up?

author: @IMindiffernt
text: Yes, when he woke up on the beach he was in Limbo with Saito. We don't really know exactly how he found him other than he is in a dream so he can manipulate the world however he wants and they were the only two people in the world with an actual conscience (or sub-conscience) so they would be naturally drawn to each other. When Cob finds him, he convinces him to "come back" with him to reality. Saito then reaches for a gun and they wake up. This implies that they used the gun to kill themselves, supposedly returning to the real world.

author: @Jakeykeywheels17
text: Mick Jimmy ok, another question, why is it that Cobb was stuck in limbo with Mol? They could've killed themselves at any time to wake up it seems

author: @IMindiffernt
text: Ah yes they didn't for the exact same reason Saito didn't kill himself before Cob showed up at the end of the film. They didn't know they were in limbo. You have to remember the line where Cob explains that dreams seem real while they are in them, and this effect is even more prevalent while in limbo to the point that its almost impossible to separate dream from reality. Remember when Cob found that house while he was in limbo and put the spinning top in the safe? That was how he convinced her they were in limbo, because to her, a spinning top represents a dream.

author: @Jakeykeywheels17
text: Mick Jimmy but they were building cities with their minds.... they thought that was real?

author: @IMindiffernt
text: Yes exactly. Remember we, as the viewer, know that they were dreaming, but they thought building and destroying cities was just part of their reality. It all comes back to when Cob says that dreams seem like reality while we are in them, but its not until after we wake up that we realize how absurd they actually are. Which I've always thought was brilliant because so much of the film hinges on that 10 second explanation.

author: @Jakeykeywheels17
text: Mick Jimmy but what about when ellen paife first starts training, her and Cob are just awake in a dream, but they know they are dreaming.

author: @IMindiffernt
text: They weren't in limbo though. I don't think its ever explained exactly how they know they are dreaming in those scenes, but I think its safe to assume that they were aware because they just know what to expect, or maybe something about the machine allows them to be cognizant of the fact that they are dreaming. Either way, that ability seems to be severely limited or even lost entirely while in limbo.

Different characters repeat the same lines, suggesting the entire movie is fantasy and not reality.

text: Well, hard to call any soundtrack the best as there were so many magnificent works... It is probably not even best of Zimmer as he gave us earlier incredible Gladiator (with Lisa Gerrard) and later magnificent Interstellar. There are also Polderius's Conan soundtracks, Bladerunner by Vangelis,  Dracula by Killar, Star Wars by Williams, numerous movies by Ennio Morricone and many many more. And - although it is a tv show not a film - Game of Thrones soundtrack by Ramin Djawadi is also very, very good.

author: @UnknownUser-vm7kp
text:
He is obviously dreaming:

- no ring (have one in dreams as he dreams of his nuclear family complete)
- children's faces revealed (haven't before due to that being the memory simply)
- totem was there to confuse people; the concept of the totem is dependent on its owner:

It has been made clear that if you utilize your own totem; it will reveal to you if you're living in someone else's dream - that's it; it does not tell you if you're in reality and hence that theory is dismissed for that reason and due to the fact, that it's simply not his totem.

author: @camerondiaztwin
text:
They are at first when he sees them through the window. When he grabs them, they are clearly older. He's not dreaming anymore. 
This is underscored by two facts: there are two sets of actors playing the children, and the dreidel (spinning top) is not Dom's totem. It was Mal's. His totem was his wedding ring, which he was always wearing in his dreams. For a split second in this final scene, you see that his ring is gone.

author: @Aribethe
text:
This is my favourite movie of the past 15 years (at the very least). So the following observation doesn't diminish my enjoyment of it at all...

But if Fischer knows that these dream corporate raiders exist (and he does - his mind was trained with specific resistance against any dream raiders), then shouldn't he interpret all of this as just some attempt to hijack his dreams? So he inexplicably falls asleep, and all the people he's sitting next to are involved in his dream. Shouldn't he attribute his sudden urge to break up his father's empire to his mind being hijacked?

author: @Kujakuseki01
text:
CameronDiazTwin ...he has next to no dialogue in this scene. He does some good faces, but this is all stage direction, music and editing making this an exceptional scene.

He was out in the cold doing method acting in The Revenant. Good for him. That's not "acting". We need to see his range and his proficiency with complex dialogue. Leo is great at yelling and I think he gives a wonderful performance in this film and in The Revenant. It's really quite wonderful. 

It is not, however, Oscar-worthy. You're looking at him through your teenage-heartthrob-"Oh, he was so dreamy in Titantic" glasses.

text: Like a lot of people here i have thought a lot about this ending. The obvious thing is that the dreams can be compare to movies (the different sets of environnement, the team they put together to build the dream...). From there i can tell it doesn't stop spinning, cause we don't see it stops, a movie like a dream cease to exist once it's done and at the end of the movie it's still spinning. Plus Cobb is not looking at it in the end, if he doesn't see it nothing can tell him if he's in a dream or not. But us as we watch the film it can tell us if we're in a dream aka movie or not. So i'd say that the movie itself has to be consider as the first layer of dream and as viewers we are the ones travelling throught all those dreams aka movies.

author: @Dante02d12
text:
So, I just wanted to throw my 2 cents about the "wedding ring theory" when I saw that comment, so here I go ^^ (and sorry if what I'll say was already said, I didn't bother to read all the comments).
Assuming the wedding ring is actually Cobb's totem, *why would he use the spinning top instead during the whole film?* If his wearing the ring is a totem, Cobb doesn't need to do anything to understand he's dreaming or not (as he would just feel the weight around his finger if he's in a dream).
What about Mal, by the way? Why would _she_ use the top in the first place? Why doesn't she use her wedding ring as well? The ring is much more practical.


Because of that, this theory doesn't hold up. If the wedding ring is shown only during dreams sequence, that's more likely because it's the symbol of Cobb's dependance to his wife. He only lets her go in the end.


Inception's end is *meant to be open.* Anyone suggesting the end is clear and has a definite answer... *is plain wrong.* There is no true answer. Is Cobb in the reality in the end? Cobb himself doesn't care (which is why he doesn't check the top in the end).
Source: https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jun/05/christopher-nolan-finally-explains-inceptions-ending

author: @xarachne8473
text: @Dante02d12 to trick the others around him into thinking the top is his totem. He tells them straight up that he spins it to see if hes in a dream or not. Others can use that info against him and make it stop spinning in their dreams to make him think its real, when hes actually using the wedding ring.

author: @Dante02d12
text: @xarachne8473 The only ones who know about the trick is his colleagues. Why would any of them trick him into thinking a dream is the reality?

author: @xarachne8473
text: @Dante02d12 dude cant trust anyone. Besides, anyone hed want to keep that info from could find out one way or another

author: @xarachne8473

author: @Dante02d12
text:
@xarachne8473 Yeah, you'll admit that it's kind of a stretch, don't you think? ^^


Besides, Nolan himself said the point of the movie was to *show the subjective nature of reality.* Putting a clear answer to the end of the movie would _totally_ go against that very idea.

author: @xarachne8473
text: @Dante02d12 so you think Cobb would just let someone trick him?

author: @Dante02d12
text:
@xarachne8473 I'm saying nothing in the movie shows Cobb as a paranoiac, which is why I call it a stretch (meaning it's *not impossible, but not supported by anything* but people's beliefs).
On the contrary, the movie keeps showing that Cobb uses the top as a totem, and once again, Nolan himself said there was no clear answer as the point was that reality is subjective.


There's also another obvious point I forgot to mention.
According to the theory, if Cobb wears the ring, he's in a dream, right?
*But in the flashbacks that happen in the reality, he does wear his ring.* Hence, the totem simply wouldn't work (since back then he wears the ring both in reality and in dreams, so it's pointless xD).
Hence, his wedding ring was not his totem back then. Hence, he had something else as a totem. so now... why would he change his totem to his wedding ring?
Now I know what you'll say: "okay, the ring was not his totem back then but he started to use it as a totem after Mal's death."
Not impossible, but again, let's be real, it's a stretch. Nothing supports that idea.


That's the problem with this theory (as with many theories): *most of it is a stretch based only on the belief of the one who started it and the others who follow.*


If we stick to facts (hence: what the movie shows and what the director said): *the movie is intended to be open, so its having an answer would destroy that very idea.*
I close my case :) .

@Dante02d12
text:
@sir-dolphino He didn't say the _word._ But that's still what he did say for anyone who knows how to use a brain.
Caine didn't know what scene was reality and what wasn't. Nolan told him that so that he *considers* his scenes are his reality. Again,  the point was that reality is subjective.

https://www.gamesradar.com/inception-ending-christopher-nolan-interview-leonardo-dicaprio-michael-caine/#:~:text=Christopher%20Nolan%3A%20the%20answer%20doesn't%20matter&text=%22The%20way%20the%20end%20of,levels%20of%20reality%20are%20valid.%E2%80%9D

I quote : "[Cobb] was in *his own subjective reality.* He didn’t really care anymore, and that makes a statement: perhaps, all levels of reality are valid."

Nolan answered to Caine in a way that he CONSIDERS his scenes are reality. To further the point that reality is subjective. What is real for Caine's character may not be real for other characters... *and is absolutely not objective reality.*

Next time you call someone an annoyance, do your homework first.

I'll add that the point of subjective reality is obvious when you watch the movie. I'm still baffled at the number of people who don't understand the point of an OPEN ending: it means there is no objective answer, because if there is, it's not open anymore. It doesn't mean we can't discuss it, on the contrary, that's the point. But trying to force your opinion on others is just toxic as fuck.

author: @CaNtwAkEuP
text:
"In the great tradition of these speeches, generally someone says something along the lines of 'Chase your dreams,' but I don’t want to tell you that because I don’t believe that. I want you to chase your reality. 

"I feel that over time, we started to view reality as the poor cousin to our dreams, in a sense….I want to make the case to you that our dreams, our virtual realities, these abstractions that we enjoy and surround ourselves with - they are subsets of reality."

"The way the end of that film worked, Leonardo DiCaprio’s character Cobb — he was off with his kids, he was in his own subjective reality. He didn’t really care anymore, and that makes a statement: perhaps, all levels of reality are valid. The camera moves over the spinning top just before it appears to be wobbling, it was cut to black.

"I skip out of the back of the theater before people catch me, and there’s a very, very strong reaction from the audience: usually a bit of a groan. The point is, objectively, it matters to the audience in absolute terms: even though when I’m watching, it’s fiction, a sort of virtual reality. But the question of whether that’s a  dream or whether it’s real is the question I’ve been asked most about any of the films I’ve made. It matters to people because that’s the point about reality. Reality matters."

Christopher Nolan

Then he was about to wait for the answer, when he saw the faces at 3:00 ( by the way the first time in the whole movie ). At that moment he just wanted to hug his kids and in the end he didn't care about it anymore. Nolan wanted to give the answer to the question: It does not matter. As long as you are happy, it can be real or not, it simply doesn't matter. What matters is the love to his kids

text: +Dancinglings but there is one problem.if this last scene  was his dream and he accepted to live in it why he didn't choose same dream but also with his wife in it.he was begged by her to do that and live in dream with her and their kids and he didn't wanted to and now he accepts to live in a dream with a kids and without his beloved wife.I think that this is reality and totem was going to fall before all went black.

author: @Nuurix
text: dekapitatorr Its not about it being a dream or anthing. He doesn't care if it is a dream or not thats the point. Not saying he KNOWS its a dream and he decided to live it. Im saying he doesn't know it (metaphor: he didn't look at the result), because he doesn't care about it he only cares to be with his children again and seeing their faces again ( metaphor: After looking at the totem, he looks back at his childs and never looks back). You have to look at this scene metaphorically. The totem stands for the infinite question; Is this reality? ( thats why the totem spins infitly when its not, because realising your current reality is not real, means you will always turn in a circle asking that question, because that question can never be answererd ). The children stand for his children, but also metaphorically for all of his desires in his life ( family etc. ). The faces stand for the emotional aspect of that ( cobb says he cant even remember the faces anymore, and thats the most devastating part of his sad relationship to his family). You have to realise, that he didn't say " this is a dreamworld and I dont care if it is fake, I will live this as my reality". What he said with that scene is "I don't know if this is reality, it mgiht be it might not be, but in the end it does not matter what matters is the love to my children and my desire to be free from that question of reality ( thats why he walks away from the totem ). This last scene is the epitome of movie endings imo, because it does not only give the question ( is this real ? ), it right away gives the answer to it within seconds ( Does not matter, all that matters are my children and I better not care about the result of that totem ) . That is beautifully presented in a metaphorical sense so people can figure their own ending out of this. My interpretation is not giving the answer to the whole debate about the reality, I just point out the intention of Christopher Nolan with this scene. A life lession he wanted to convey to the audience. Thats what he always does with his movies and thats why I believe he is a living legend on this planet. A true genius and I am more excited for the next movie of his, than anything else. A true masterpiece this movie and especially the ending.

author: @dimonai01
text:
Ok then why not just run to his kids from the start, if all he cared about was being loved? The point of the ending is that his kids all along were his anchor to reality. if you hadn't noticed throughout the movie he couldn't bare to look at his kid's face. we can only speculate what he was seeing but it probably wasn't their true face(he said it himself). his kid's were his totems. noticed how he's the only one who knows what they look like? even the audience doesn't know, why is that (cough totem cough)? Cobb was lost and basically had no real sense of what was real or not throughout the movie, but his kid's, that he knew for sure. the spin top was not his totem, it was his wife's, the ending was not the first time in the movie that he didn't wait for the spin top to finish spinning.

 the ending is not as ambiguous as everyone wants it to be, if you base you assessment solely on that final scene and ignore everything that happened throughout the movie then of course it will seem like a 50/50 whether he's dreaming or not, but there is enough evidence throughout the movie that strongly hints that he's not dreaming compared to absolutely zero that he's dreaming (seriously name 1 legit piece of evidence that isn't 100% speculation?). the toppling sound at the end was just the icing on the cake to relieve any doubts you may have about the ending and also so that you may look at the movie differently next time around. just like the prestige, you'll catch a lot of clues that were right in your face once you saw the ending making the movie still enjoyable after multiple viewings.  again if all he cared about was the love of his kids, not reality, then the whole movie was a waste of time.

author: @dimonai01
text: no there are literally no clue in the movie that he is still dreaming, please name one? people keep saying that but can't name a single legitimate clue. again this open ended ending that everyone illogically clings too is not based on facts and would literally make this movie a complete waste of time. Christopher Nolan is too good of a writer/producer/director to make rubbish like that. none of his movies have ever had an open ended ending that would make everything that happened in the movie irrelevant, that's bad writing. hell i can't think of a decent movie that has an open ended ending that made everything irrelevant. there is nothing wrong with an ambiguous ending, the problem is that the ambiguity in this movie that everyone seems hung up on would again make everything that happened IRRELEVANT. if you want to see what a truly perfectly executed ambiguous ending looks like, watch the 1982 movie "the thing", now that's a truly ambiguous ending that can go either way and doesn't take away from everything you saw throughout the movie. Nolan's movies aren't about the ending, they're about seeing if you payed attention throughout the movie. memento, the prestige, the dark knight,  interstellar, etcs.. the ending are always a conclusion to big and small events that you may have missed but were right in front of you the whole time, they then become a lot more noticeable the next time you watch the movie.

author: @Iguana93
text: Very nicely said. Firstly, I think the whole "it doesn't matter if it's reality as long as you're happy" is shaky at best. It sounds poetic and kind of nice, but I don't think the idea of being stuck in you head, living essentialy in the confines of what your own brain can think of, is nice at all. You have to be pretty confident that the world around you is "real" to feel your life has any meaning. The idea which Cobb gave his wife was stronger than it was supposed to be, but that doesn't mean Cobb didn't have that same idea in himself already. He just wanted to get back to his kids. If he could stay happy in some construct of his head, it would be fake and his kids would still be orphaned, which sucks and really is an equivalent of "if you drink yourself to stupor or drug yourself, you'll be happy and won't mind that your kids are in a different country". But all this aside, as you said, the simple fact that he could see their faces meant they were real, and if that wasn't enough, the wobble of the spinning top right before the cut couldn't be more obvious and definite. It must have fallen a second after the cut. It baffles me how anyone can not see that.

author: @alexkunst1344
text: Seeing that this all was a dream is so simple. Just look at that fact: Nolan is a director that always goes into great detail describing characters, even the characters that aren't "real" main characters. Just think about Alfred, two Face, the Joker, Jim Gordan and all the others in the TDK trilogy or Murphy and Brand and Romilly in Interstellar . Now, in this movie, all characters except for Cob and Mal are described incredibly shallow, something that Nolan would never do. I mean, those characters don't even have last names, they are just "Saito" and "Ariadne" and "Arthur" and so on. This is, because the entire movie was a dream and all the other persons therefore are projections of Cobs subconscious only, and projections are always very shallow. There is about 10 more hints that this is a dream, just take the time and watch https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ginQNMiRu2w , it is really really worth watching.

author: @alexkunst1344
text:
I think that everyone who likes this movie should watch the video "Inception and Philosophy" by Kyle Johnson. Because only through this video, the pure genius of the movie is revealed. 
Everyone is talking about how the top is spinning and that it might fall or might keep spinning. But the totem is no use at all to tell Cob if he is in reality or in a dream. This is because of the idea of a totem. Every totem doesnt behave normal in the real world. Take, for example, Arthurs totem. It is a prepared dice that will always show the number 5 when you roll it. If Arthur now goes into another persons dream, this persons dream will apply the normal laws of physics, because thats how the real world works. So in a dream, the number will be random, when Arthur roles the dice, because the dreamer doesnt know that Arthurs dice is prepared. That way Arthur knows if he is in a dream or not.
Now, with Cobs totem it is the opposite. If you spin a top in the real world, it will fall down. So if Cob is in someones dream and he spins the top, 99% of the time the top will fall down ANYWAY because it is that way in reality, so the dreamer will make it happen in his dream anyway. That means, that Cob could still be in anyones dream if the top falls down or if the top keeps spinning, it just doesnt matter. Because if it keeps spinning, he most definatly is in a dream because in the real world the top would fall and if the top falls down he could still be in a dream because the subconscious of the dreamer thinks that that is what would happen in the real world.
The pure genius in this scene now is the deception by Christopher Nolan. He draws the attention of the audience to the spinning top and wants them to figure out if it will fall or not. But the most important part of the movie is the conversation that Cob has with his son in the background: Cob asks "What were you doing" and his son replies "We were building a house on a cliff". 
Throughout the whole movie we have seen, that the subconscious works it way through in the dream. The best example for this is the train that suddenly rolls down the street in the first dream. It is a subconscious element from Cobs Memory of his and Mals time in the limbo when they laid down on the train tracks and let themselves get killed by the train. 
 So now his son tells Cob that they have been "building a house on a cliff". And building a house on a cliff is exactly what Saito had been doing in his Limbo. He was living in this Huge Japanese Mansion by the sea. So this means, that Cob is still in a dream. Because prior to waking up on the airplane, Cob was in the Limbo. But if you die in the Limbo, you go one layer up. We know this, because when Ariadne and Fischer jump from the building in the limbo they wake up back in Eams dream of the snow Fortress. So when Cob dies in the limbo, he cant wake up in "reality", in the airplane. When he shoots himself with the gun in Saitos Limbo, he goes up one dream layer to the snow Fortress. But this layer is empty now, since Fischer has opened the safe and thus finished the inception and everyone left the dream through the kick. So now Cob fills this drean with his own expectations, thus making it his own dream. Since he expects to wake up on the airplane in the real world again, he wakes up in the airplane, but its not the real world, it is still the snow fortress dream.
That way, this very sentence in the ending tells you that the entire movie, even the "reality" of Cob flying in the plane and now coming home to see his children is still a dream, because Cobs subconscious fills the dream with the information of building houses on a cliff, which Cob has experienced before when he was in Saitos limbo. But whether he knows if its a dream or not, Cob does not care anymore and accepts this dream as his reality. This is shown through his kids. In the dream where Mal told Cob to look at his kids faces, he refuses to do so because he is afraid that, if he will do so, he will want to stay in this dream and not come back to reality. Now, even if Cob knows that he is in a dream because of his sons response, he still plays with his children and accepts this dream to be his reality. He had struggled to do so before: just remember the scene where his father in law, the professor, tells him "come back to reality" when he visits him at the university. This is his subconscious telling Cob to wake up, and he is torn between finally waking up to the real real world and keeping on dreaming, but ultimately, in this scene, he chooses, whether consciously or subconsciously, to keep on dreaming.

author: @hastobe303
text:
+Ty Garner 
If this is the case, he's still asleep in his home and Mal is probably awake in the real world. Seeing as they killed themselves by train while in limbo, they only jumped one level up. Therefore Cobb is still dreaming the dream he shared with Mal, and Mal is either one level up or she killed herself enough times to wake up.
In other words, if this is the case nothing in the movie actually happened. 
Also, the spinning top feels different in the dream world than it does in the real world. So it has two qualities: perpetual spinning and different "feel" (not sure if it's loaded, like the die, or what's the matter with it). 
However, the top belonged to Mal, and therefore Mal alone can know the true feel of the top. 

This is not THE correct explanation, though. There are so many interpretations to this ending and Nolan hasn't really come out with any information on what really happens. So unless you are Chris Nolan or you've extracted this information from Chris Nolan's subconscious, you really are in no position to say what is and what's not. All you have is a hypothesis. It could also be argued that Cobb died in all the other dream levels due to not waking up in various dangerous situations, thus waking up when he dies in limbo.

Furthermore, I wouldn't really recommend Kyle Johnson's lecture. He has some good ideas but it was really hard to focus on the film analysis because of his intense shouting and screaming throughout.

author: @lastuchiha007
text: Aavione Howard You do not know whether it's a dream or not. It could be or could not depending on what you think and interpret. Some people say that because Cobb woke up and was with his family, that he finally got home and it is reality, like with the totem wobbling. But other evidence points that the ending is a dream, an in my opinion it is a dream. After Cobb wakes up everything happens too fast, and no dialogue is made with the other characters. No sleeping equipment is found. Lastly, when he meets his kids, the son says "I'm making a house on a cliff." This is a reference to Saito, who lived in a house on a cliff in his Limbo. If the kid mentions this, odds are it is not a coincidence, and therefore the ending is a dream. Other evidence shows that the entire movie is a dream, which makes more sense than everything else that's being said.

author: @AYZEEMAN
text: Aavione Howard The idea is to make you wonder whether at the end he is dreaming or not. There are many theories about the film, all could be correct or false. 1. The whole film is a dream, similar conversations keep happening with different people suggesting that it is all a dream, for example both Mal and Saito talk about a leap of faith. 2. The inception is not what we think it is, it is actually Saito incepting Cobb, Saito wants this company destroyed so the only way to do that is to get Cobb to do a job for him, Saito plants the idea in Cobb's mind by using his relationship with his wife and his family, by making him believe he can get back to his family, when really he is just going to leave him in limbo. 3. He is dreaming at the end. 4. He isn't dreaming at the end. Personally I think number 4 is correct, we hear a lot about totems throughout the film, but never about Cobb's totem, the table top spinner is his wife's totem. Upon looking back at the film everytime he is dreaming he is wearing his wedding ring, at the end he is not wearing his wedding ring (as seen at airport security). So he is not dreaming at the end. I believe his wedding ring is his totem.
