author: @LightBrand
text:
How is it that a no-ending cop-out is been seen as intellectual and deep in today's storytelling rather than a shortcoming in writing where the creator don't have to come up with any answers for the complex (and often intriguing questions) he/she raised?

Because people are clearly saying Nolan had answers, but just intentionally didn't want to share it right? Not because he himself have no clue how he wanted to tackle the problems.

For all you "deep" viewers that say the ending was deliberately done by Nolan to show Cobb no longer cares if he's in a dream or not, so whether the top falls over makes no difference, therefore Nolan cutting away early is justified. Even though we all know had the movie continued for 2 more minutes, Cobb would have entered the house with the kids, and he'll see the top on the table. He'll have one expression if it tipped over, he'll have another if it kept spinning...

If Nolan truly wanted to show Cobb stopped caring, he could have had DiCaprio toss the top into the trashcan on his way out the airport. Wouldn't that still leave whether he's in a dream ambiguous, but he/we no longer cares? That's giving answer yet keeps the ending ambiguous (but it no longer matters).

Makes me wonder why the Soprano ending caused such an outcry.

author: @kevtb874
text:
I'm not sure the real/fake thing should be debated as much as some people do. 
The real trick here is the fact that you doubt what you've been shown because the top takes so long to fall and we never see it. Questions creep forward. It COULD be fake. Even though the entire movie and its themes have been about Cobb coming to terms with things and getting back to his kids, we wonder if that's really what's going on. Because an idea has been planted. An idea that sticks in our minds. 'What if this reality is a dream?' The audience has been incepted.

author: @3sweetsugarhoney3
text:
As someone who's watched Shutter Island and Inception for the first time both in the last 20 days or so, and someone whose favorite movie is The Prestige just like it is for you, I couldn't disagree more. Shutter Island was quite a disappointment to me, its plot twist being very predictable (so predictable, actually, that I thought there would obviously be a second plot twist that would be the real deal, but no, that never happened). Inception doesn't really have a plot twist, from the very beginning (or as soon as you understand what the movie is about) you consider the possibility that what you're watching could be also a dream, and indeed, at the end the possibility is still open.

 What makes it great is the amount of different interpretations you could get out of it, which goes way beyond the "was it a dream/wasn't it" discussion. Are other characters projections of Cobb's mind, representing other people in his life? Was Mal trying to go back to limbo and Cobb trying to save her, or was she the one trying to save him, and in the end killed herself to go up another level, noticing they still weren't in the real world, something Cobb refused to acknowledge? Is Saíto just Cobb's projection, and saving him from limbo is the excuse to save himself? And is the complicated father-son relationship between Fischer and his father just an excuse for Cobb to deal with his own guilt for abandoning his kids? Is Cobb playing an inception on himself? Is someone else implanting an idea in him? There's a world of possibilities, plus many visual and plot metaphors (something that's also very present in The Prestige) and the emotional conflict in the character. Those are things you won't find in Shutter Island. Shutter Island ends, and that's it, you get your "unexpected" ending and there's barely any place for discussion about it. But, of course, it depends on what kind of viewer you are. If you are one of those people who want certainty and don't enjoy having doubts about the story and what you've seen, you'll hate Inception, or take it in the most simple way possible (by the end he's back in the real world with his kids, the dream is over, everyone's happy, lalala), and you'll feel that Shutter Island is better because its only possible ending seems more complex and tragic than a happy ever after. But if you don't mind a story that is open to the viewer's interpretation, I don't see how you could prefer Shutter Island over Inception.

text: Bodhi for every argument one makes there are hundreds counter arguments. However there are clues that narrows down the search fields. There have been plenty of clues laying around the internet and we are pretty much convinced about everything about primary purpose of inception, and whose dream was the primary host.And it was indeed Fischer's The only ambiguity was whether Mal was incepting Cobb's dream, and if Cobb's dream was the primary host. If she was trying to incept Cobb, she would have attempted positive measures- Hence they were all Cobb's projection depending on how she was before she took her life. In short, Fischer's dream served as primary host, Mal was just Cobb's projection, Cobb's admitted that it was his fault for Mals demise, but redeemed himself of it so that he can peacefully join his family....

author: @peterb7790
text:
The top keeps spinning. Throughout the film Cobb is refered to as "an old man, filled with guilt". In Nolan's story Cobb creates the perfect dream layer, wherein his subconcious can't attack it. This is what we see in the last scene and the proof can be found in Nolan's extended script, which you can purchase. 

Moreover, and a point from my own observations, Cobb and Miles suddenly appear from the airport straight to his house in the last scene. "In a dream you know where you are but not how you got there" or whatever the quote is, said by Cobb to Ariadne, when he has her hooked up to the machine for the first time. I also think this is a hint to it still being a dream, as Nolan had to cut the details from the final script but still wanted us to know.

author: @tailorednightmare8542
text: I'm going to explain to EVERYONE why that top stops spinning and he successfully made it back to REALITY and his kids and not Inception. It's SO SIMPLE; you can hear the top wobbling as if it's about to stop spinning which when in a dream, it spins perfectly in place without a slight wobble. BUT that's not it. The true answer lies in his kids. Remember him saying no "matter how hard he tries to recreate that last moment he left them, he can NEVER recreate their FACES" and here you can clearly see them. Their faces, their smile, their life. I like how the director left it for us us to have fun with it. Kinda like choose your own ending type game but it took me watching this movie over 20 times to figure it out. (Not only because it's my favorite story/book/movie in the ENTIRE UNIVERSE! but because I had to solve it one way or another.) It's SIMPLE. He cut it right before the top stops spinning so it can make that IMPACT in all of our minds but the answer is clear: he could NEVER recreate his kids faces in Inception so this scene my friends is a true happy ending.

author: @RoySherfan
text:
I've posted this on another Inception vid but I'll repost it here:

Remember this bit in the Cafe scene between Cobb and Ariadne:

Cobb: (to Ariadne) Let me ask you a question, you never really remember the beginning of a dream, do you? You always end up right in the middle of what is going on.
Ariadne: I guess... yeah.
Cobb: So how did we end up here?
Ariadne: We just came from the... ah... (She looks stumped. She could not remember how they got to the cafe).
Cobb: Think about it, Ariadne. How did you get here? Where are you right now?
Ariadne: (a sense of revelation grabs her as she looks at Cobb): ... We're dreaming?
Cobb: You're actually in the middle of the workshop right now, sleeping. This is your first lesson in shared dreaming. Stay calm.


Now... back to the end of Inception

Question: Did Cobb remember the beginning of his "dream"?
Answer: Yes, he woke up in the plane seat.
Consequence: If he remembers the start then there is continuity from his last point of consciousness. He WAS dreaming. He WAKES UP in the seat. It makes sense. There is temporal continuity.

Question: How did Cobb end up at his children's place?
Answer: He METHODICALLY entered the United States of America - performed mundane actions such as filling out immigration forms and presenting his passport to the customs officials. He walked through the gates at the final checkpoint and met his friend and they both made their way to the house. All the while, Cobb is looking around rechecking himself and his surroundings.
Consequence: The methodical nature of reality is you can't teleport from one location to another. Moving from the airport to the house requires a long arduous process. Each moment of this arduous process is reinforcing to Cobb that this is in fact real.

I believe this is a very strong cue that is designed to show the audience that, well, that he is NOT dreaming. The fact that he is in the process of making his way methodically from the airport to the house is a strong case to it being reality.


Other points: The Totem
A totem is an object that is used to allow the dreamer to check if they are actually in someone elses dream world. If the dreamer is the architect then the totem will feel correct. The totem only works if they are in someone elses dream world.

From this:

1. If Cobb is dreaming in someone elses dream then his Totem will feel off.
2. If Cobb is dreaming in someone elses dream then that architect will have to know what Cobb's place with their kids looks and feels like.
3. If Cobb is dreaming in someone elses dream world then all the people in it are a part of his subconscious - but if Cobb is the architect then none of the people in it are part of his subconscious.

Thus, the fact that he is in his house (impossible for another architect to fake) and the fact that he has continuity from the point he wakes up to the point he meets his children build a strong case that this is, in fact, reality.

The only thing left ambiguous at this point is whether the totem appears off to him... and obviously Nolan doesn't give us the luxury of knowing that. Hence.... we are here talking about it. Yeah... that Nolan guy. Props to him!

author: @Alex-wk5ic
text: No, it wasn't. Mal’s shadow stabs Cobb during the film’s climax, which throws Cobb back out into Limbo and onto the shores of Saito’s limbo house. When Cobb has to “wake” again in Limbo, his mind is muddled just like old man Saito’s brain. Through Saito’s memory of Cobb’s totem and some shared dialogue that included key trigger phrases – “Leap of faith,” “Old man full of regret, waiting to die alone,” etc. – Cobb and Saito are able to remember the meaningful conversations they had and that there is a reality they existed in before Limbo, where both of them had deep desires still waiting to be fulfilled (Cobb and his kids, Saito and his business). Once they remember that limbo is limbo,  they are able to wake themselves up (likely with a gunshot to the head).

author: @TheWambo333
text:
I'm sorry but I don't think the wedding ring is a totem. Why?

He doesn't even notice it a single time. It's just a nonrelevant detail produced by his subconscious, like all those random people in the city, you can't even remember but are somehow produced by your mind.
In every of Cobb's dreams, his wife is alive. Result: subconscious produces the wedding ring automatically.
If he would dream of her being dead, the ring wouldn't be there neither but as the movie told us, he can't do that anymore.

So what is Cobb's totem? Well I think he has two of them.

The first one is his wife being alive. Like I said before she is alive in every single dream and only there.
The second totem is the fact he can't or don't want to see his children's faces while he is dreaming a 'lie'.
He only can accept to see them at the top, the reality.

Now look at the final scene, his wife is finally gone and he is able see his children, both things that would never have happened in a dream. Not exactly the way the original (physical) totems work but a personal indicator for him to define a dream.
The spinning top is also a useless totem and really a symbol/keepsake for his wife (as it belonged to her). He learns to ignore it in order to go back to reality just like he did with his wife in the deepest level.

So it doesn't matter if it falls or not, he ignoring it and then look at his children (reality) instead is the important thing.
Classical Mind F***


Then think back to the scene with Ariadne at the Cafe.
What is the first thing Cobb teaches her about a dream? - You never know how you got there.
What is the first thing Cobb tells Fischer at the hotel to show him it's a dream? - You never know how you got there.

Well we literally saw how Cobb got to the final scene. He left the plane, passed the airport check, got picked up by his dad and arrived at his house. He didn't just appear there out of nowhere like in the scenes before (hotel, snow base...)

author: @michaeldecker4341
text:
I just watched inception again with fresh eyes, and here are some thoughts. 

Life is a journey of many dimensions, a battle of many layers, within your own mind.  

Reality is subjective, its not where the spinner stops spinning, your ideal reality is the 
one you arrive at when you overcome the paradigms and programs that drag you down.  

This fight, or as in the movie, this 'seemingly improbable' flight, is the battle.

The deeper you go and the more layers you peel off and stare down, the faster your progress time will go, as
represented by the speed of time the more dreams then went within the dreams.   

Cobb's wife represented guilt.  Guilt wrapped in a beautiful layer, with the strongest emotions attached like love, 
the shared creation of children, and the guilt that his wanting to control her contributed to her decision to end her life. 

And that's just one emotion, wrapped up in so many layers, seemingly impossible to break all combinations.  

But that's what we all have to face to then channel the supreme creative force into our lives.  You don't have to
overcome it all at once, but you have to surrender to this ultimate battle and start the war.  

Limbo is what happens when you give up in the middle of the battle.  You get lost in whatever world you currently 
chose to die and slowly decay and who knows how long it will take to wake up. 

This movie is Cobb's limbo.  He was lost, he had given up to the temptation of Guilt's wrath many times.  

When Cobb woke up on the plane that look on his face is, wow, I can't believe I made it and how much I 
went through to let that guilt go.  

The banishment of USA just meant Cobb wouldn't allow himself to go back because of guilt.  Once the 
opportunity offered itself and he was ready for the challenge, he took it. 

I think what happens in this movie all happens on the flight and after the flight.  I don't know if it's the same flight, but
where Cobb wakes up is where the movie also started--even if it may not show that. 

The point is not that the movie inception was a dream, but that what we call reality is a dream, and therefore, probably
a dream within a dream--multiplied by infinity.   

And since your life is most  likely a dreamed existence, within a dreamed existence, that all you can do is use the tools
and awareness that you do have to create the life you want.  This means, first, confronting the inceptions that have
infected your mind and ideas that have taken deep roots and facing and letting go of all those layers of things like 
guilt, remorse, unloving, etc.  Whether they are attached to your parents, your childhood, your relationships, yourself, or a mixture 
of them all.

author: @TheWambo333
text:
Jenna Lacroix
Well, let me destroy your 'evidence' real quick then.

First,  Cobb's totem:

The spinning top is NOT his totem, it's his wife's one and I think almost everybody will agree with that, if not go and watch the movie again. It's just a misleading symbol for both Cobb and the audience.

So what is Cobb's totem? Well I think he has two of them.

The first one is his wife being alive. She is alive in every single dream and only there.
The second totem is the fact he can't or don't want to see his children's faces while he is dreaming a 'lie'.
He only can accept to see them at the top, the reality.

Now look at the final scene, his wife is finally gone and he is able see his children, both things that would never have happened in a dream. Not exactly the way the original (physical) totems work but a personal indicator for him to define a dream.
The spinning top is a useless totem and really a symbol for his wife. He learns to give it up in order to go back to reality just like he did with his wife in the deepest level.

So it doesn't matter if it falls or not, he ignoring it and then look at his children instead is the important thing here.
Classical Mind F***

Then think back to the scene with Ariadne at the Cafe.
What is the first thing Cobb teaches her about a dream? - You never know how you got there.
What is the first thing Cobb tells Fischer at the hotel to show him it's a dream? - You never know how you got there.

Well we literally saw how Cobb got to the final scene. He left the plane, passed the airport check, got picked up by his dad and arrived at his house. He didn't just appear there out of nowhere like in the scenes before (hotel, snow base...)

You still can think the ending is a dream but therefor everything you see also needs to be part of a dream, including the whole mission, the team, the dream sharing itself, hell even the story of Cobb and his wife.
So what would be the point of this movie if everything is fake? Not very likely imo.

Of course this is just what I think, I don't want to say it's the only true meaning of the story, just what matches the best from my point of view.

author: @jennalacroix1347
text:
Not quite destroyed at all, since you missed something. It's stated that you don't wake up immediately from the Limbo, the deepest part of your mind, into reality.
So, while Ariadne and the others waked up layer by layer, somehow, Cobb and Saito appeared, from the lowest level, into reality.
Instead of waking up in the snowy place. The bad thing about missing this little detail, is that all of the theory is now screwed up. It's like a math problem, one wrong number and the whole problem will be wrong.

 I've watched the movie 3 times now, I don't need to watch it again, so, do you remember who left the van? Ariadne, Fischer, all of them. Only Cobb and Saito are never rescued from the sinking van.

Therefore Cobb is actually dreaming and is in the third layer and the others are indeed in the real world because they were "Kicked". But Cobb and Saito were left in the van while they were still in the dream. since the others have already woken up. There is no one in that dream layer to wake Cobb and Saito up.﻿

Also, the top continued to spin until Cobb was reunited with his children, being aware of it or not, he didn't even care anymore. When he saw his children, he accepted the dream as reality and that's when the top started wobbling. ﻿
Many people claim the top was about to fall, and indeed it was, because Cobb was now in the same situation as his wife, his dream became now a reality, and since it's a reality now, the top should stop.

Not to mention, in the 2-3 times Cobb spins the top during the movie, it lasts around 15-20 seconds tops.
The most solid proof (or one of the most) that he never made it out is the fact that the top spins 50 bloody seconds, twice as longer.
It's when he holds his children that, for him, that's his reality now :)

Back in the dream, Cobb was going back for Saito, and they should have woken up in the third layer, the snowy place. Since it's stated you can't wake up directly into the real world without going layer after layer.
However he "wakes up" all they way from the deepest later into the real world, and you are not shown how that happens, since it doesn't happen at all.

The reason the top starts wobbling is because the moment he hugs his children, he embraces that as his reality, therefore the top stops spinning. As I said, the top spins for almost a minute, something impossible, and suddenly wobbles when he hugs his children. :)

author: @TheWambo333
text:
Jenna Lacroix
The real world is not the van wtf!? o.O
It's the plane etc.
The van is part of the first layer.

However the movie never told us how to escape the limbo. The limbo is not a standard dream like the layers before, so you clearly can't tell that they need to wake up in the snow layer in order to get out of there.
This only applies to the standard dreams...

If Cobb already escaped the limbo once, how would he not recognize still being stuck in a dream this time? Makes no sense at all.

The top isn't a totem as I already pointed out before, it's his wifes totem and so it doesn't work for him. It's just a misleading symbol for both Cobb and the audience.

author: @jennalacroix1347
text:
TheWambo333
It's logic! If you can't wake up, for example, from the 2nd layer directly into the real world, how could you possibly wake up from the deepest of all layers, the Limbo, straight into reality?

And yes yes, sorry for that, the van was the 1st layer, anyway, the point stands. Remember they were sedated in the plane, when you die in the Limbo and you do not wake up (Because of the sedative) you enter a state where you no longer know if you are dreaming or not. Just like Cobb's wife suffered.

I know the top is not his totem, and it's not that he doesn't recognize he's in a dream, it's the fact that afyer finally seeing his children, he does not longer cares, that's his reality now. And in that reality, the top (Whether it's his totem or not) should stop spinning.

It's very hard, you have no idea how many theories are out there, and how many people claim it's a dream and how many say it's not.
I truly believe there is no right answer, since there is always a missing link in both theories.

author: @44excalibur
text:
Altair150
“The way the end of that film worked, Leonardo DiCaprio’s character, Cobb – he was off with his kids, he was in his own subjective reality,” said Nolan. “He didn’t really care any more, and that makes a statement: perhaps, all levels of reality are valid.”


The film-maker used the spinning-top puzzler to make the point that reality and dreams do not exist in mutual isolation. “In the great tradition of these speeches [to undergraduates], generally someone says something along the lines of ‘chase your dreams’, but I don’t want to tell you that because I don’t believe that,” he said. “I want you to chase your reality.”


Nolan added: “I feel that, over time, we started to view reality as the poor cousin to our dreams, in a sense ... I want to make the case to you that our dreams, our virtual realities, these abstractions that we enjoy and surround ourselves with, they are subsets of reality.”

So it's not a dream, it's just a metaphor that we each find our own reality, and that's why Cobb didn't bother to even check to see if the top was wobbling and about to fall. Nowhere does Nolan say that the top doesn't tell Cobb if he is dreaming or not; he simply says that Cobb doesn't bother to look at the end, and that's why he cuts away before the top can fall.

author: @jillum89
text: "It doesn't matter" is bullshit? The purpose of the video is to explore the ability to solve the problem of hard solipsism. You _could_ possibly be hooked up to a computer being fed information of what you "believe" is the "real" reality. You _could_ be dreaming right now. You _could_ be hallucinating. You _could_ be in the matrix. Can you prove that you're not?  In other words, can you solve the problem of hard solipsism? _Your_ statement is that "it doesn't matter" is bullshit. So if it _does_ matter to you, then you can't live your life without knowing. That's your statement. So let's hear it. What's your solution to the problem of hard solipsism? Because you would be the first and only to have ever really solved it then.

author: @TheJunkalos
text: Jillum89 Argument From Ignorance or Non-Testable Hypothesis

author: @jillum89
text:
Hmmm, could you explain? I know that ordinarily "Can you prove that you are not?" is an argument from ignorance, but is it here? I'm not saying that because she can't prove that she's not in the Matrix then therefore she is in the Matrix. I never said that, but that _would_ be the argument from ignorance. I challenged what seemed to be her claim.

As I explained, I asked Marina this because she said that the whole "it doesn't matter"-bit is bullshit.﻿ Implying that it _does_ matter to her to know. So all I did was ask her if she knew. Or if she actually did live a life without knowing, thus showing that it doesn't matter if you ultimately know; you can still live and love and play and all. :) Essentially, all I wanted to do was to show the point of the movie. I didn't make an argument, I asked a question about what she said.

author: @TheJunkalos
text:
Jillum89 
1. You cannot ask someone for "proof" when there is no way to acquire or test it. 2. You didn't say "therefore she is in the matrix" true, but you did write "You could possibly be hooked up to a computer being fed information of what you "believe" is the "real" reality. You could be dreaming right now. You could be hallucinating. You could be in the matrix." all this to NOT infer that she is in the matrix?.
3 You ask again at the end for an answer that no one can acquire the answer to man.

4. All this "you could" is just a lack of commitment to this idea. Do you believe it or not?

author: @jillum89
text:
1. "You cannot ask someone for "proof" when there is no way to acquire or test it." Of course I can. When someone says that knowing X is important to them, then of course I can ask them if they know X or if they know not Y. It's not my problem if what they think they know or should know is something hat cannot be known for the reasons you say. That's their issue, not mine.
2. "You didn't say "therefore she is in the matrix" true," Great. Because that is what the argument from ignorance would be. "... but you did write You could [be X, Y and Z] all this to NOT infer that she is in the matrix?" Yes, all this to_not_ infer that. Because 1) She and you and I could also be living in the ultimate reality. And 2) How could I infer all these scenarios at once? I already explained what they point was. It's nothing but a challenge to what she said. And not in order to say _Therefore you could be in the Matrix!_ but in order to show that she is living a life without knowing. So may be it's not as important to know as she said. And that's great. Because I don't know either.
3 "You ask again at the end for an answer that no one can acquire the answer to man." Again not my problem.
4. "All this "you could" is just a lack of commitment to this idea. Do you believe it or not?" Do I believe what? Btw, since I wrote this comment I've understood the logic a little bit more. And I've understood that there's a great difference between "You could be X" and "You can't prove that you are not X". And now understanding that, I would actually change what I wrote. I don't even know if it is possible that one could be in the Matrix. I just know that I can't prove that I am not.

author: @TheWambo333
text:
My first conclusion is that the ending is real, let me explain why and please excuse my english.


First, Cobb's totem:

The spinning top is NOT his totem, it's his wife's one and I think almost everybody will agree with that, if not go and watch the movie again. It's just a misleading symbol for both Cobb and the audience.

The wedding ring is also NOT his totem, he doesn't even notice it a single time. It's just a nonrelevant detail produced by his subconscious, like all those random people in the city, you can't even remember.
In every of Cobb's dreams, his wife is alive. Result: subconscious produces the wedding ring automatically.
If he would dream of her being dead, the ring wouldn't be there neither but as the movie told us, he can't do that anymore.

So what is Cobb's totem? Well I think he has two of them.

The first one is his wife being alive. Like I said before she is alive in every single dream and only there.
The second totem is the fact he can't or don't want to see his children's faces while he is dreaming a 'lie'.
He only can accept to see them at the top, the reality.

Now look at the final scene, his wife is finally gone and he is able see his children, both things that would never have happened in a dream. Not exactly the way the original (physical) totems work but a personal indicator for him to define a dream.
The spinning top is a useless totem and really a symbol for his wife. He learns to ignore it in order to go back to reality just like he did with his wife in the deepest level before the Limbo.

So it doesn't matter if it falls or not, he ignoring it and then look at his children instead is the important thing.
Classical Mind F****


Second, Cobb is experienced in escaping the Limbo, we are not:

A lot of people think that he made it out of Limbo but is stuck in the now empty snow base level, where he just thinks of the flight/children scenes. Why do I think this is not very likely?

Well, the movie tells us that Cobb already did escape the Limbo before.
How would he not recognize still being stuck in a dream level this time? Doesn't make sense to me.
Plus they never told us how to escape the Limbo, did they?
So how do you know he has to go through all of those stages in order to make it out?
I think he knows better than we do ;)


You still can think the ending is a dream but therefor everything you see also needs to be part of a dream, including the whole mission, the team, the dream sharing itself, hell even the story of Cobb and his wife.
For me this would get way to abstract and hard to combine.

Of course this is just what I think, I don't want to say it's the only true meaning of the story, just what matches the best from my point of view.

Let me know what you think :)

Not only that, but Cobb is not wearing his wedding ring.. Which means he is in reality. Also, since he is with Micheal Caine, it means he is in real life, Caine developed the dream sequence.. author: @TheWambo333
text:
The fact that he remembers how he got there at the end is a strong indication that it's real, also with Caine, the plane, airport and all those happenings we consider being real during the entire movie, also just being a dream, where the hell would all of this start? I mean seriously, how would this movie make sense if there is no part being real at all.
This just would get way to weird and complex, so I also think the ending is real but I only watched the movie once, maybe I will change my mind within time :P
Anyway the wedding ring theory is nonsense, it's a detail produced by his subconscious mind, not a totem.
He always wears it in his dreams because his wife is only alive in there -> subconscious mind produces ring.
If he would have a dream with his wife being dead, the ring wouldn't be there neither but he can't do that as we can see.

author: @Bovvmen
text:
This is why I think that Dom actually escapes limbo:
When he and Saito are underwater, it is agreed that they have died are in limbo. This is because Saito is shown as an old man. Essentially, the sedative had to wear off at some point, but in order to escape limbo, you had to acknowledge the dream state and then find a way to escape (EX: when Dom plants the idea into Mal's mind that death was the only escape when they were both in limbo). While in limbo, we see that Saito remembers the arrangement he had made and they say "Come Back" (meaning they have both acknowledged that they are in limbo). I presume that in order to escape, Saito shoots both Dom and himself (immediately before they escape and Dom wakes up in the plane, we see that Saito is reaching for a gun). Furthermore, while on the plane after escaping limbo, Saito makes the phone call, acknowledging their agreement.

author: @heels9933
text:
No one should eliminate the idea that he is still dreaming because 1) Mal did ask the right questions, why were anonymous corporations chasing him in random parts of the world? 2)Mal said the reason Cobb could see the kids, was because they were projections in his head, this goes perfectly with everything Arthur says about inception. 3)Cobb can't sleep without inception, so he would do it all the time while in his "real world". In one point of the film, one of the characters say that eventually their dreams become their reality. 4) the totem that Cobb uses the entire time, was Mal's totem. It was HER object to use to determine reality. And each person had to create their own, it was so crucial to have their own, that another person couldn't even touch the other's totem. Ariadne had her chess pawn she created, one of the others had dice etc. My point is, they never showed Cobb having his own totem, therefore from the start, using Mal's totem is flawed. The totem he uses in theory, doesn't serve the function it was intended to, because it's not his. So, does it even matter if it was spinning or not? If it's not his totem, of his own creation, then it can't help him determine what is and isn't real. 5) And lastly, the totem WAS still spinning.
What if, when Mal jumped from that building, she ACTUALLY WOKE UP TO THE REAL WORLD. It's insane and very possible. I feel that Mal had a better grip of reality, considering Cobb had so easily gone dream in to dream, and at one point ended up in limbo. He wasn't careful.
I'm not saying he was in a dream for sure, but I think some people are too confident he woke up. I, on the other hand, have no idea what to believe. Hence why this movie is brilliant.

author: @adampage593
text:
I never understood how people would think he was still dreaming. We know that the spinning top never stops spinning in the dream world, so that bit right at the end where it starts to wobble is a sign that the top is losing momentum, and as such, will eventually fall. If it were to keep spinning, it'd still remain upright, the little wobble at the end is essentially saying "Yeah, he got out"
Had Nolan cut the scene before the top started to wobble, I'd understand that people would question it, but the wobble is essentially the reveal. The wedding ring theory, while still good, and essentially solidifying the whole ordeal, is kind of unnecessary, kind of like saying Gravity still has the same effect on lighter objects which fall slower.

author: @danielroy4808
text: I sometimes get frustrated with studio executives - and indeed critics - who will watch a film in a very linear way and make notes as they go, because that's not how movies work. You get to the end - the audience gets to the end - and then you take about five minutes to decide 'OK, what was all that?' and your brain really looks at everything in a different way and then you decide. And that's why endings are so important and that's why you really have to get to the end of a movie before you know what it is. -Christopher Nolan-

author: @whoryare
text:
i have two theories: 

1. everything that happens after cobb tries the sedative for the first time is a dream. they said 5 minutes of sleep is worth about an hour... and the people in that "den" using the sleeping machines (i dunno what they are called) are there for 10 hours on some occaisions. after he tries the sedative he goes into the bathroom to wash his face and goes to spin his totem, but drops it and before he can try again, he leaves the room and you dont see him spin it again until the final scene of the movie.
2. all the "inception" was to try and pull cobb out of limbo. he was stuck in his dreams trying to keep the memory of his wife alive so they go into his subconscious and plant the idea of all this elaborate stuff to get him to realize hes dreaming. i think the scene where he sees michael caine for the first time and he says "come back to reality" shows that. also, watch the scene where saito is an old man and cobb has gone into limbo to get him, but imagine that saito is talking to cobb instead of the other way around (if that makes any sense) and then look at the expression on leo's face when he talks to the old man saito and also when he wakes up. also, you never actually see them kill themselves, so they could have just been hooked up to the "inception machine" and it finished (remember when ariadne tries it for the first time? he says try another 5 minutes, so my guess is they can regulate the time of the dream).

author: @ginofactap
text:
Aka5787658 Cobb used a spinning top as his totem, he himself (in his mind) decided that in his dreams the spinning top never ceases to spin, that's what totems are for in the movie. a way of telling yourself whether you're dreaming or not. for somebody else was the weight of a ring, or some like that. that's the principle, it basically changes with every totem, since every totem is personal.

the point in this ending though is that it doesn't really matters to him anymore whether it's a dream or not, at the moment he sees his kids he stops caring about the spinning top. he stops caring about reality or dreams. he gets to be with his family again, and that's all he wanted.

author: @Xact_Lee
text: Aka5787658 If you want it to fall then it falls. Keep in mind that that is ONE totem. A totem is not only unnecessary but the main way for it to function is simply being the only one who knows its weight. The spinning isn't key to all totems. This one is just more efficient and easier to use because there are 2 ways to tell; weight, and eternal or limited spinning. If you wanted it to fall, that would take away that way to tell if it's your dream. Then again, what _I_ don't understand is why he told the architect girl how it works... cant she now just construct a dream where the top never falls?

author: @Jabberwocky869
text: Mal's totem: in the dream she can will the top to spinn forever (because otherwise it's physical characteristics alone would be enough of distinction, but it was all about the ability of unlimited creation); in the real world she cant. Cobb's totem: in the dream he can will it on his finger and since he know it's every physical characteristic, no one besides Mal can manipulate it; in the real world he doesn't wear it on his finger. After Mal's death the top becomes the symbol of his guilt and inception and much more reliable reality check, because Mal's projection wants him to stay and could manipulate his totem like he did hers (he certainly believed his wife knew everything about his wedding ring). But even Mal's projection couldn't manipulate her own totem, that's what his guilt was all about, and it became his totem, till he let go of his guilt and in doing so could go back to using his own totem without fear Mal's projection could meddle with it.

author: @shizolein
text:
@Aka5787658 sorry for being late, the answer to your question is: 

remember, you're supposed not to show anyone else how your totem works, right (keep that in mind)?

So, let's say, Cobb is in the real world: The totem is doing what physics ( keep that in mind) makes it to do: after a while, it stops spinning and drops off. 
Now, think of Cobb being in someone else's dream: if the dreammaker doesn't know of Cobb's totem "behavior"- which is to stop spinning after a while, how the dreammaker can make it "behaving" just like in the real world? Right, he/ she can't.

It's just the same like in one of the first scenes with the wrong carpet surface.

At least this is my theory. 

But this theory doesn't make it legit a 100%, because, let's say Cobb is still in limbo. How should his totem not work as he is kind of his own dreammaker? He knows exactly how his totem behaves in real world, so basically, I think the totem will stop spinning at the end. But after all this will not tell you, if Cobb is still in limbo or not.

It's more likely that Cobb gives a shit about it and enjoys the whatever it is quality time with his kids.

I know it's very late, but that triumphant song lasts right until we see the top.

 I think its meant to reflect what we feel, as opposed to Cobb. It was constantly unsure and discordant as we felt a state of unreality and unease throughout it, not knowing the full story. author: @expedion6005
text:
Ok, for those that say that Cobb's ring around the finger tells if hes in a dream or not is not necessarily true. Because the ring finger on and off (ring on being a dream and ring finger off being reality) could pretty much be something that he's constructed in his 1st layer of dream state. See, Cobb tells occasionally about how he and his wife finally woke up from the dream but his wife was still skeptical about it being reality, she might've been right and that she committed suicide because she knew it was another dream layer. So Cobb was essentially stuck in the dreamstate himself, with the belief that his wife killed herself because she couldn't differentiate from reality and dreamstate. When in fact, it is Cobb that can't differentiate between reality and dreamstate because he believed that to what he awoke to with his wife, was the reality. So therefore Cobb has also constructed an entire belief in this dreamstate in which hee got stuck: That his wife is dead because she couldn't differentiate between dream and reality, that he shouldn't wear the ring and so forth. But in the end, Cobb is the one stuck in a dream with bunch of characters around him. So when they speak about a 3rd layer dreamstate. It's actually a 4th layer dream state. Because the 1st layer dream state is Cobb's baseline of his own living dream of which he believes is the reality and in which he has strongly convinced himself that his wife killed herself in the real world. (when it's actually Cobb's first dream layer that he's living in with the belief that THAT is the reality). So Cobb.... is still stuck in a dream. He just came back to his 1st layer. Or who knows, might be that he slipped into a 5th layer state in which he uses his 1st layer to project its characteristics upon the 5th layer state (The state that he awakes to in the plane).

So, was he in Saito's dream? Da hell, the entire idea that he works for some organisation that specializes in extraction of dreams, could be Cobb's entire dream.  Because after all.... you're never told about how he got in the entire extraction field in the first place. It's all just the instant assumption from the get go that he is some sort of skilled extractor... So inception 2, could actually be a nice sequel telling the story before he slipped into a dreamstate. What happened before all of that? What was his REAL life like? Interesting stuff.

author: @roo7227
text:
Luke Li

But that's only because he perceives that reality as "real".. Watch the movie, again, and see if this explanation makes sense..

The kids are not real.. THEY ARE THE INCEPTION.. Just as it was explained about how the inception would be executed to Cilliain Murphy's character (Fischer), by implanting on one level, then reimplanting deeper, the kids are first mentioned by Moll, in the very first scene of the movie (when Cobb uses her to weight the chair so he can tie a rope to it and vault down to the floor below, to access Saito's "safe").. Then, the inception is reimplanted with the phone call at the flat before the helicopter ride with Saito, and Saito's offer to return to them (the kids, and the US)..

This would explain quite a few things, such as why Cobb sees these kids everywhere he goes?.. Wouldn't that be consistent with how "inception" was explained, earlier in the film?.. That it grows like a wild fire?..

And one thing that bothers me about any other explanation, is why Moll and Cobb would ever explore limbo in the first place, if they had kids?.. That, literally, makes no sense, at all?.. They wouldn't abandon two young kids because they wanted to be some kind of half-assed pioneers, would they?..

Plus, there are other clues, such as getting caught in obvious mazes, and the characters always just arrive where they are going, like in a dream.. It all adds up to, IMO, the inception was happening from the opening credits of the movie..

In the house, Saito shot himself and went one layer up which is suppose to be filled with Fisher's subconscious. But Fisher and the rest had already woke up. So, when Saito went into that layer, he automatically will think he is in the plane, and when Cobb went into the layer, he will be in Saito's subconscious. Which is why it can also be that he is stuck in Saito's dream when his children seems like Saito's subconscious. :)

author: @EnGrapefrugt
text:
The movie is about dreams, right? And in dreams everything that's impossible can become possible. That means that even though the totem might look like it's about to topple it can easily get steady again and keep spinning. We do not know the answer if it will fall or not before we literally have seen it fall with our own eyes. 
Now, I am not saying that what I believe is the right thing but I'm pointing out that there is another opportunity how this movie ended.

author: @inukag01234
text: Honestly, you don't need to get upset about it. You can look it up if you like. Cobbs said himself that one should never explain their own totem, nor whether it's a realistic thing event that occurs in the dream or not. It's never stated that the totems in the dreams HAVE to defy laws of physics/reality. Also, Inception is not a real event, so whether you are wearing a ring or not is irrelevant. Can you prove that it's the only totem Cobb has? Can you prove that that's HIS totem?

author: @inukag01234
text: People, people, please. The reason he explained the spinning top totem to everyone is because it is not his totem. His wedding ring is his totem. He only wears it when he is dreaming, and does not when he is awake, because he feels more attached to Mal when he is dreaming. The top totem is Mal's totem, which is why he was free to explain it. In this scene, he's not wearing the ring, therefore, he's not dreaming.

author: @PlucharC
text:
I will watch it, however...

If you're going to distract the audience with a red herring of sorts, that's fine, but you can't also distract your main character with it, unless he's in the same position as the audience.  In this case, you've already established that he's not by saying that he stole the top (his wife's totem) and that his wedding ring is his totem.  

So, we're back to, why is the character so focused on spinning the top?  And why isn't he checking his wedding ring?

author: @PlucharC
text: I'm with you part way.  But why the emphasis on the top then?  And if he knows how his own totem works, why isn't he checking that to see if he's out or still dreaming?

author: @PupCake1025
text: Guys! I know the ending! In the movie, there's a brief scene where Cobb breaks into his wife's safe and takes her totem- the top. This is NOT Cobb's totem. His totem is his wedding ring- in all his dreams, he's wearing it. In reality, he's not. That means the ending isn't about the top falling, it's about his ring. If you watch this scene, he's not wearing his ring. That means he is, in fact, NOT dreaming. You are welcome.

author: @Blueynoes
text:
Watch the movie first or youll spoiled the ending.

He's spinning that thing to test if he's still dreaming. In his dreams, if he spins it, it never topples. In real life it does. So if it doesn't fall over, he knows the world he's in isn't real. However, then he sees his kids' faces, and no longer cares (it was mentioned earlier in the movie that he never saw their faces when dreaming and longed to see them again).

It's been over a year since I saw, but thats how I remember it.

text:
Whether the top keeps spinning or not is irrelevant. It's not his totem, it was his wife's. Your totem is supposed to be unique to you, something that no one else knows the physics or feel of. 

Mal was right. She woke up when she jumped out the window. Cobb is still in deep slumber. Mal's appearances in dreams are her attempts at performing inception on Cobb, to get him to realize that he needs to break limbo.

Ariadne is Cobb's projection, a defense mechanism to fight Mal.

author: @nadianoodle27
text: The ending of Inception is meant to leave you thinking and questioning the nature of reality. The important question is not "Is Cobb still dreaming?" -- What is important is the fact that the character of Cobb goes from being a guy who is obsessed with "knowing what's real" to ultimately being a person who stops questioning and accepts what makes him truly happy as what's real.

author: @ashieboy1995
text:
3. The kick and Saito. This is how we know for sure that Cobb's team made it back. If they died before the sedatives ran out, they would be trapped in limbo, but, with the kicks, they wake up in each level, going back up to reality. Cobb however would have to use the gun as his extra kick to bring Saito back with him. If he didn't use the gun to kill himself, he wouldn't be waking up in the plane. He'd still be speaking with Saito (Old saito).

So, we can say that he is not dreaming

author: @ashieboy1995
text:
TBH, I don't think it could be explained simply with the wedding ring theory. However, I would say that Cobb is not in a dream.
1. Limbo traps a person and makes them believe they are in reality. The only way out, is by dying. Even if Cobb got trapped in Limbo with Saito, they can get out via the gun. We dunno what happens as it's not shown
2. Patterns in dreams. Remember, in dreams, the subconscious never speaks to the dreamer. But, Cobb speaks to Alfred, his children, and airport person

author: @w00tEpixx
text: And anyway, the most important part of the ending is not whether he was dreaming or not. It is that for once in his life, he just does not care. At the beginning of the film he is psychotic, ready to kill himself at any time, checking every now and then to see if it is reality or a dream that he is living. At the end, he does not even take a moment to make sure. He lets go, and keeps living in the moment, embracing his long-lost happiness.

author: @w00tEpixx
text: You should know better than to flat out deny the possibility that he is not dreaming. That's the beauty and magic of the ending of the film. You cannot really tell, but in either case, it makes your hair stand up. Personally, I've read arguments of both sides, but I believe he was dreaming, because I find that ending to be more fitting and it emotionally stronger. It's all in the eye of the beholder.

text:
It really doesn't matter whether the totem spins or falls. At the end we see that it clearly spins on longer than it normally would, yet at the end it starts to falter.

I think what we're supposed to take away is that it no longer matters whether he's in a dream or not, because Cobb has accepted reuniting with his kids as his reality. It's real to him, meaning that even if he were in a dream he wouldn't want to wake from it.

author: @MrYosssup
text:
let me rephrase it: If I was Christopher Nolan I would have had 3 choices:

1) showing the damn thing falling, which was going to happen but it would have not been such a creative ending.
2) showing the thing keep going..that would have been a disappointing ending
3) cutting it right before falling so to create a more interesting ending.

option number 3 was the smartest option and Nolan is smart. I really doubt he had other second meanings..especially philosophical ones.

author: @gorgolyt
text: It's ambiguous. That's the message. If they cut it whilst it was spinning without wobbling, it wouldn't be. If they cut it after it fell, it wouldn't be. The director's intention for the meaning of this scene was ambiguity, and therefore that IS the meaning of this scene.

text:
A fun movie to watch but REAL inception is simpler than this & doesn't require all the technology, drugs, etc.  It can also be done while the subject is in a completely conscious state.

It's called Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP).  NLP can make people forget & plant ideas into their mind.  It's like being a psychic pick-pocket.  But not only can you remove thoughts, you can put them in the mind.

Checkout "Neuro Linguistic Programming Demonstration" on YouTube by FaithLessTOWH.

author: @NateChannelInc
text: It's literally impossible for the ending to be a dream, meaning that Mal really was crazy due to Cobb's inception. My logic is that, if it was a dream, then when Mal's projection killed Cobb in limbo with the butcher's knife before Ariadne jumped off of the building to kill herself to get back to the van, Cobb woke back up in the van. But he wanted to die again to get back into limbo to get Saito. Well, that probably took at least 2 minutes, (continued in attached comment)

author: @NateChannelInc
text: which would be months in limbo. Cobb died and went back to Saito, which is why Saito was so aged because it took so long for Cobb to get back + to find Saito. Cobb wasn't that aged when he found Saito because Saito had been in limbo longer. When Cobb killed himself (and Saito) in limbo, they both woke up and Cobb didn't drown. If Cobb had been in a dream when he got back to reality where he sees his kids' faces, then when Cobb died in limbo, he would've went straight back to the real reality.

author: @Vi0l3nttDFO
text:
( Icopy and pasted this, ur theory isgood but thre are plentyofholes)
Plenty can be assumed from this. We can assume that the ending must be reality. We can assume that the ending reality must be linked to the rest of the reality throughout the film. Or maybe we can assume the ring stood for the guilt that Cobb held onto Mal, and once he got rid of the guilt, he no longer wore the ring since Mal has been let go from his subconscious. This, of course, then suggests that the conclusion is a dream.

text: The entire point of the ending isn't about the totem and whether it's a dream or not. It's the fact that he doesn't care whether he's dreaming anymore because he's finally reunited with his children. We can never know if it is a dream or not (no matter how much evidence you provide it wouldn't matter, the evidence was placed there for a reason - to mislead you - not to inform you of the true answer) is what makes this film stupendously amazing, the film's a masterpiece.

author: @nacreserut
text: @papermariodude101 it's not a fake ending because the goal of the story has been accomplished. The main conflict driving the story is not that they need to steal a secret from someone's head, but Dom's lingering feelings for his ex-wife. In the end, he resolves those feelings and finally moves on, he has catharsis, so it does not matter whether we know if he is in a dream world or real world. We know that Dom is finally at piece at the end and that's what makes the story beautiful.

I'm in awe of its truth, in its ability to make not only me, but all who've watched it ponder, and the fact that every time I see this end scene, I. Smile. Period. The movie is a diamond amongst a landfill of coal that is Hollywood. I believe it will be a while before another movie comes along that will make us think, have healthy debates and allow us to enjoy cinema at its finest. Cheers.

author: @KBShantuma
text:
Es ist recht einfach.
Leo (so nenn ich ihn) wurde auf Grund von Verbrechen (Extraktion) gesucht und musste seine Familie verlassen.
Sein letzter Wunsch ist es die Gesichter seiner Kinder wieder zusehen, weil er sich diese nicht vorstellen konnte (somit tauchen sie auch nicht in den Träumen auf).
Der Auftrag vom Japaner ermöglicht ihm zurück zu seiner Familie zu gehen.

Der Kreisel dient nur zur Ablenkung, denn durch das Sehen der Gesichter weiß Leo das er nicht träumt.

author: @treotube
text: The wobble suggests *near certainty* that it's all real, but the scene dramatically cuts out before we get 100% confirmation. Hmm, to me, that sounds like real life: Everything is probably real, but there's always that morsel of undisprovable doubt (e.g., Descartes from Philosophy 101) that maybe there exists something higher to wake up to. Cobb was young, life was sweet, so he could ignore it and just walk over to his kids. But Saito was old and alone in limbo, so that doubt was his only hope.

author: @buu678
text: the point is whether not the top will spin perfectly as if it is running on perpetual energy. that is the difference between a dream and reality. the laws of physics only apply in reality. If the top wavers even slightly from a perpetual perfect spin then it means some external force is acting it like gravity or inertia so he must be in reality. Nolan didn't let it drop because he wanted to confuse those who weren't paying attention.

author: @themanclaw2
text: I have seen it many, many times myself. Think about how Cobb just walks away from from the top without even looking to see if it fell. That really shows how the point is that it no longer matters "because we'll be together".

author: @InterpolFL
text: Whether it keeps spinning or falls is immaterial; the significance of the final scene is that Cobb has decided he is content with this form of reality and is no longer obsessing over whether his top falls or continues to spin. He has gotten back to his kids, he is allowed back in the U.S., and if it's all a dream it matters little to him since this reality is what he was striving to achieve. Reality in itself is only what we choose to make of it, who's to say reality isn't a never-ending dream?

author: @DayAfterDay56
text:
Just to add to the idea that it doesn't matter whether or not it was a dream, Mal's riddle is an allegory for Cobb's ambitions throughout this movie. "You know where you hope this train will take you, but you can't know for sure," could mean that he wants to go back home, but won't know whether it will be real or not once he gets there. "But it doesn't matter because you'll be together."
Dream or not, Cobb is back with his kids and happy.

The top wasn't even his totem to begin with, and even if it was, he would know everything about it - therefor if he was stuck in his own dream, he would never know anyways. That's the whole point of the movie. We don't know if anything is real or a dream in the first place.

author: @ziggyBmon
text: No, the top spins and spins only when dream sharing. If not dream sharing, the top would obey the laws of physics in the mind of the dreamer and would wobble and fall down. That was the whole point of totems, when dream sharing the totems properties would alter.

author: @ziggyBmon
text: No, only Cobb is dreaming, remember, once Cobb released Fischer from that limbo state, he was still there with his wife coming to terms with her. Once Fischer started to wake up, the team had no choice but to disconnect the machine, leaving Cobb in a coma. This scene is Cobb in limbo making his world based on a successful Inception of Fischer. The wobbling top at the end only signifies that Cobb is no longer dream sharing.

author: @SengokuTheGouda
text:
It's movies like this that make me wish we could some how wipe our minds. To see this again for the first time would be fantastic. The wonder, the excitement, the edge-of -the-seat ending, the audience collectively raging when it cut to black. 
This, Lord of the Rings, and a very select few are movies that, if I find out a friend hasn't seen, I have to be there for their first viewing, as that's as close as I'll ever be to seeing these for the first time again.

author: @SengokuTheGouda
text: The best reason for why this is reality: the top is not his totem. The movie explicitly told us that it was Mals, and outlined the rules for totems, the main one being that only you should know what it is and how it works. Everyone knows about the top, so it's useless as a totem. When we see Cobb spin it, it's more out of regret for Mal. His totem is his wedding ring. Or that's just the greatest continuity error of all time.

author: @encryption
text:
The spinning top is a red herring to incept the audience with the idea that his still being in a dream depends on its falling or not. The very idea of a totems effectiveness could be part of a dream.
Hint: At the end Cobb asks his son "What are you building?". His son replies, "We're building a house on a cliff!"
What is the first thing Cobb sees at the beginning of the movie when hes washed up on the shore? 
This implies subconscious thought continuing as a thread, as it would in a dream state

author: @cart00n_rabbit
text:
So from that alone, you've figured the whole thing out? The cliffhanger is solved by the fact that we never saw the spinning top wobble before? Really?

The ending is *deliberately* ambiguous. There is no conclusion to be drawn, because it isn't necessary in order for the real point to be conveyed: Cobb doesn't care about the totem any more.

author: @kidlewis
text:
that's not how I see the ending. It's much more involved with the viewer than that. 

The inception is on the viewer, you as a film watcher. It's up to you to decide whether he has awoken or not, not Cobb. 

When the film ends did you think "great film" or did you sit there in amazement wanting more, wanting it to be real, wanting to know whether he did awake or not? 

I think he did and I wanted more, I felt like I was 9 years old walking out of Jurassic Park hoping it would become real.

author: @kidlewis
text: People try to work out what the ending is about but I read a blog which makes it very simple. The inception is on the viewer, it is you who decides wether he has awoken or not, whether it was all a dream or not. When the film ends did you get up from your seat an think "good film" or did you sit there wanting more wanting to know. That is what Nolan wanted with that ending

author: @cart00n_rabbit
text:
Christopher Nolan has stated that the most important thing about this scene isn't whether or not the spinning top falls, but the fact that Cobb isn't looking at it. He doesn't care whether this is reality or not, because he has finally been reunited with his children.

I think it's better to interpret the scene like this rather than keep needlessly debating whether or not Cobb is dreaming. It's deliberately ambiguous, and to make up your mind one way or the other is to miss the point.

author: @mcalsooner91
text: To me, I feel like Cobb is living his "dream". The whole movie was centered around his inner demons and why he could never see his family and that pain was tearing his mind apart. Once he "killed" Mal in limbo, his mind is finally at peace. He does NOT care anymore if he is dreaming or not because he has finally defeated his demons. He is at mental peace and happiness again and could care less if he is dreaming or not since he has finally made it home to see his children.

author: @LarryGarfieldCrell
text:
Exactly.  That's the point.  The ending is balanced just right that you can't say for certain if he's still in a dream (however many layers down) or if he's finally back in the real world.  It's deliberately vague.  That's what's so awesome about the ending. :-)

Anyone telling you that it's "obviously" one or the other is blowing smoke up your arse.

author: @MarcLagace88
text:
I picked this up off of another video, but finally got around to testing the theory. 

Listen to what his son tells him they've been doing at the very ending, before the camera pans back to the top

"We've been building a house on a cliff..."

A house on a cliff... A perfect description of the opening scene of the film where Cobb washes up on the beach of Saito's limbo. What an oddly specific thing for his son to say... Unless Cobb didn't jump all the way to reality.

He's still dreaming.

author: @peacocean
text: The ending, in my opinion, is reality. The totem he spins is not his totem, it is in fact Mal's. You can therefore not worry about whether it tumbles at the end or not. author: @majafaja999
text:
Anyone see the common theme that Nolan tries to explore in his movies - the notion of creating our own reality - real or fake - that will make us happy 

Memento: Lenny chooses to accept his reality that John G is alive and his search is never-ending, but that keeps him happy
Dark Knight: Alfred burns Bruce's letter & Batman takes Harvey's fall to preserve his reputation and keep Gotham hopeful
Inception: Cobb ignores the totem and chooses to see his kids instead 

Just Saying...

author: @blackholewasup
text:
This movie presents a great thought analysis-all things come from thought, even dreams.  The houses people live in, work in,etc.
Everything is real and nothing is impossible.  There is no such thing as 'not real.'  People are always creating their own reality through sub/conciousness to the elemental world around them made of atoms.  In other words, there isn't even really anything there, only raw material fastened together, i.e. wood, plastic, etc.  Man uses for itself.  Light moves fastest.

author: @JimJava007
text: Here's my theory: The spinning totem at the end isn't for Cobb-it's for us.  It's letting us know that the movie isn't real, and that it's time to come back to reality.  That's why the "Dream is Collapsing" music plays over the credits- haven't you noticed how, when a movie ends, the illusion of reality it creates comes apart?  The audience "awakens" to the real world.

author: @MattRebecca
text: Didn't read all the responses, but my take is the whole movie is a dream. What we see in the beginning is when the dreamer falls asleep and starts dreaming. When the screen goes black at the end is when the dreamer wakes up from the dream. In the movie it's explained that you never know how you got there, you're just in the middle of the action. Think about how a dream happens.. it's like being in a movie or watching one.. what happens when you wake up? The screen goes black and you wake up.

author: @AlexxxzA1
text: In order for Cobb to be in Limbo, he (who knows that Limbo is not real) would have to build an airplane, recreate all his team members, create and populate LA, and then create his children two years older. And also create a Limbo where tops wobble instead of spinning perfectly. Then, he would have to forget it was Limbo and "wake up" on the plane he created.Multiple cast members who worked with Nolan directly  heard his whole vision of the movie and confirmed that the ending is part of reality.

author: @mepizzasmangled
text: I think the ending is meant to be a mystery. The whole point of the movie is to point out that life﻿ might not be real; everything might be a dream, and that life itself may be a dream and death is the reality. The point is, we can never be sure. So the ending remains a mystery as we question whether Leo's reality is in fact a dream, as we ourselves question if OUR reality, or our lives, is actually all a dream. A controlled dream; as the characters controll dreams

text: Agree with all the comments on here. The music is just so beautifull and adds so much to the film particulary the ending. Life is not like that and more films like this should reflect this.

author: @Xboxlove1
text: @DieHardjagged the whole point of the shaking totem is for you to NOT know. There was no other way the director could tell the message that no one knows if it is dream or reality.  If it didnt bobble a tiny bit people would think its a dream, which isnt what the director wanted.  If the director wanted to show us its reality, it would have stopped spinning entirely (no point cutting it off). tl;dr you arent meant to know.

someone posted this on inception ost-
  "So, you know how everyone thinks that the Top is his totem, but in the beginning he mentions that it's actually Mal's? author: @Arcilios
text:
One of the best movies I have ever seen in my entire 21 years of existence.

author: @darrens888
text: @darrens888 Mr. Nolan stated in an interview that he, as a father, believes that " Cobb reunites with his kids". Nolan had been trying to hint us that Cobb returned to reality in many ways. However, the controversy lies with some viewers not wanting to accept the beautiful fact that Cobb reunites with his children.

author: @darrens888
text: @darrens888 Most importantly, the theme of family, the action, and the emotions Cobbs feels  in the movie would be pointless if the ending shows that Cobb is in a dream the whole time. Also, would it make sense if Cobb was actually some overweight McDonald manager that feel asleep in the back of the bus and dreamed of the whole inception idea? In addition the idea of Cobb in the limbo the whole time would be utterly insane.

author: @darrens888
text: @darrens888 2. When Mr.Cobb is in a dream, he wears his wedding ring, which wasn't the case in the end of the film. 3. In dreams you never get to see the faces of the children, but however, you see it at the end of the film. 4. Many viewers says that the kids wore the same clothe, BUT, if u paid attention, the girl wears different shoes at the end of the film and people can wear the same clothe many times. 5. As the top spins, it gradually loses speed, whereas it spins perfectly in a dream.

author: @darrens888
text: @darrens888 When Cobb spins the top in the hotel, it stops, meaning that he is in reality. Then he goes into 3 dream layers and into the Limbo(4 layers). As the sedative wears out, Cobb was able to kill himself and saito and return to reality as he did before with his wife Mal while his teamates ride up the synchronized kick up the 3 layers. Also, the viewers would see many small details that hints that Mr.Cobb is in reality. 1. There are 2 sets of actors for the kids, meaning that they AGED.

author: @darrens888
text:
To clear up some confusions about the ending-
Although there are contreversies regarding the ending of the fim, the FACT is that the main character, Mr.Cobbs returned to his kids in REALITY. As I have watched this film over 10 times, I have gathered a large amount of evidence which are hinted by Nolan to support the claim that Mr.Cobb is indeed in reality. Many of the viewers believed that Leonardo was in the dream in the end. However, mathematically, it adds up that Cobb was in reality.

author: @raul77him
text:
ANSWER:
"You know how everyone thinks that the top is his totem, but in the beginning he mentions that it's actually mal's? Well, you see, if it's not his totem, then it's not going to properly work for him. Cobb's totem is his WEDDING RING. Whenever he's dreaming he has a wedding ring on because, as he says, in his dreams they're still together. In reality he's not wearing a ring. During the last scene of the movie? HE'S NOT WEARING A RING. BAM, Reality."
- credit to:
Brosenthal

author: @010110ffhh
text:
Nolan purposely left the ending open to the viewers interpretation.

But the most plausible version is that once Cobb and Saito exchange a few words while sitting across from one another, it triggers their memories that they're both still in Limbo. Saito (assumedly) shoots Cobb and himself in the head to wake themselves up (The serum they took has worn off by then). Saito makes the call on the plane to clear Cobb's name. no wedding ring, totem starts to wobble, Mal is still dead=reality.

author: @roewedge
text: Whether he was in reality or not is not important to even answer. The important thing was that the very idea of that was planted in your (the audiences) head. It leaves it up to you to decide what reality is because you are the one who at least constructs the perception of it. I think another thing to note is that other people are not supposed to see the artifact he uses.. yet the audience does. Since we did no create that artifact and are seeing it we can't be sure if what we are seeing is real

text: (Sighs) Each level becomes less intricate and less detailed. A 6th Level might as well be an area the size of a room. If he was in some next level of "dream state" there would be no airline. author: @SunsetSara
text: Cobb's totem can't tell him that he is not in someone else's dream either - because it belonged to Mal and he told Ariadne how it works. So, he could be in one of their dreams. Plus, any dreamer knows that a top just falls. So, if Cobb spins his projected top in their dream, the dreamer would just dream that the top falls.

author: @SunsetSara
text: @Riwillion There's something a totem can't tell you.﻿ Arthur says a totem can only tell you that you are not in someone else's dream (because if you are in someone else's dream, it will behave in the way they expect it to - not the special way it behaves in reality as only you know). Since Cobb knows how his totem should behave, it can't tell him that he is not in his own dream. If Cobb is dreaming and he's the dreamer, his projected top will behave in the same way it does in reality.

author: @Exiio
text: @Riwillion More or less, he is right. The main reason he always checked the totem was because Mal killed herself because she thought the real world was a dream, so he always checked because he regret what happened. It's well established that the world is real, and it does show the top begin to topple over and then the movie quickly ends. By habit he spun the top, but when he saw his kids turn their heads, he just didn't care anymore about the top because he knew it wasn't a dream.

author: @SunsetSara
text: Cobb looks through a missing glass grid on a closed lecture hall door and sees Miles. Then, we get a quick editing jump close-up of Miles. Then, audio of Cobb: "You never did like your office." And then we get another editing jump where Cobb is magically sitting in one of the empty wooden rows inside the classroom. But the door is shut. We never heard the door open or close. And Miles never heard the door open or close. Isn't this a clue that Cobb is dreaming? The editing jumps are dream jumps.

author: @TheDashingRor
text: While the ending to the Prestige is mostly masterfully delivered as a montage tailored to the sagely musings of Michael Cain, Inception plays out its final moments as a careful and awe-inspiring dance to thundering motif of Hans Zimmer, and is equally impressive.

author: @SunsetSara
text: When Cobb spins the top, he’s actually using it to check and see if he’s perceiving Mal as real. The totem’s only purpose is to remind Cobb that Mal no longer exists - that his version of her is nothing but a projection. This simple idea explains why totems are not really important. Arthur, Eames and Ariadne are all shown with totems, but we never see them use it on the job. Reason: They already have a clear grip on reality.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
Pausing the Blu-Ray disc confirms:

James (at 20 months old in the opening scene) is wearing a short-sleeve plaid button down shirt that contains reddish-orange, brown, and yellow vertical stripes. He is wearing khaki shorts and brown sandals with no socks.
 
James (at 3 years old in final scene) is wearing a short-sleeve button down plaid shirt that contains red and brown vertical stripes. He is wearing dark khaki shorts and white tennis shoes.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
Pausing Blu-Ray confirms:

Phillipa (at 3 years old in the opening scene) is wearing a short-sleeve pink dress that has a two inch pleated frill trim at the bottom. She is wearing brown shoes.

Phillipa (at 5 years old in final scene) is wearing a pink dress with shoulder straps that has around an 8 inch pleated frill trim at the bottom and a waistband design. She is also wearing a white t-shirt underneath the strapped dress. She is wearing pink tennis shoes.

author: @SunsetSara
text: Cobb & Mal's totem is not weighted or balanced in the way Arthur's loaded die is. It works by "willing" it to continually and flawlessly spin. When Mal or Cobb would spin it (or anyone else like old Saito), they would "will" it to continually spin. If it fell, they were in reality. But since they can control the physics of it in a dream, it's possible they could "will" it to fall while dreaming which Mal may have chosen to do in Limbo and what Cobb may have chosen to do in the final scene.

author: @CuddleFish124
text: This really is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  The story took something that we all experience from day to day (dreaming), and turned it into a piece of art.  And the ending was so well done.  The music fit the images perfectly, and was very moving.  And yet when we do not see if the top falls or not, the music turns mysterious once more, and we are left to wonder if what we had just seen was a dream, or reality.  All in all, GREAT movie and GREAT ending scene!

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@jentario 
The problem for the "he's in the real world" stance (which I agree with btw) is that people that defend the view that "it's all a dream" or "Cobb is still dreaming" in the final scene, can argue that even if the top ceases to spin and falls, still, this doesn't prove that Cobb is in the "real world" for he could be dreaming and unconsciously "willing" the (projected) top to fall for the first time. But the ring on-off visual provides the visual evidence that he is in the "real world"

author: @jentario
text: i don't see why people are so uncertain about the ending. it's obviously not a dream... you must be blind to miss how the top's movement becomes very clearly unstable, unmistakably suggesting that it will cease spinning and, of course, that this was reality... it was merely a playful moment of suspense, were you are meant to momentarily have this unnerving doubt,  and i really don't think that the filmmakers originally planned there to be such a debate over this.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@aksstar 
Even though Fischer can't remember his dream, the inception took. And as a result of that performed inception on him (through forging the emotional concepts and identities), Fischer now has a set of false beliefs in the "real world," one of them being "I will split up my father's empire." But this and other false beliefs having to do with his father feel like self-generated beliefs for Fischer. He doesn't think twice about them. The team succeeded in faking "true inspiration."

author: @SunsetSara
text:

When Fischer awakes back on the plane after hanging out in Level 1 for close to a week (his countdown clock was set to around 9.5 hrs), he doesn't remember what he was dreaming about. He may have some blurry images of characters in his dream which is why he looks at Cobb in the baggage area. CONT

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@0pt1muzPr1m3 
That said, it's still logically possible for one to argue that Cobb is still dreaming in the end. If the top falls, that doesn't prove Cobb is in the "real world" for he could be unconsciously "willing" the top to fall for the first time while in a dream. And he could be imagining his kids are two years older. He could be dreaming his ring is not on for the first time. But any argument put forth doesn't carry as much force as the theory that he is in the "real world."

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@0pt1muzPr1m3 
Nolan has said, in his mind, there is a fact of the matter whether Cobb is the "real world" in the final scene. He also says the viewer should be able to figure out how he intended it. Given that there is visual evidence to support the view that he is in the "real world" in the end (Ring Visual) and that Nolan has said he doesn't want to alienate the audience, Nolan clearly sees Cobb in reality in the final scene as he walks away from the top.

author: @0pt1muzPr1m3
