author: @SunsetSara
text:
@DrrkAngel15 
Cobb is happy in the end. But, that's not the entire point. Nolan has said in interviews that we should be able to determine whether he's in the "real world" at the end. He goes on to say that, in his mind, there is a fact of the matter on if Cobb is in the "real world." The theory that he's in the "real world" is strongest, IMO, since Nolan distinguishes the "real world" from the "dream" scenes in comments; he gives us the ring visual; and he says he didn't want to alienate us.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@TheRheaLouie 
Nolan also says he didn't want to alienate the audience with the business of the spinning top scenes - but he comes close to doing so in the final scene. On the one hand there is a lot of visual evidence that points to Cobb being in the "real world" - for example, the wedding ring visual. But there are so many explanatory visual gaps that Nolan has purposely left out that he leaves room for multiple interpretations. It's a balancing act but he pulls it off.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@TheRheaLouie 
Actually, Nolan has repeatedly said in recent interviews, that in his mind, there is a fact of the matter whether Cobb is in the "real world" in the final scene. He says it's up to the viewer to figure it out. So, it's not a matter of interpretation...not meant to be left unsolved...but many people falsely believe he intended it to be left unsolved. Again, if the top does fall, it doesn't prove he's in reality. But there is a lot of visual evidence that suggests he is.

Also, the children playing in the same area as they were two years prior when Cobb left them does not prove that Cobb is dreaming in the final scene. author: @SunsetSara
text:
@zero00grav 
Mal didn't miss any Kick. Christopher Nolan concedes to his brother in the Intro of his book "Inception: The Shooting Script" that Mal is dead; therefore, she jumped to her death in the "real world" on her anniversary night. In the final scene, his children are two years older. Phillipa is now 5 and James is 3. When Cobb had left them and took the airline ticket, Phillipa was 3 and James was 20 months old. There were two sets of child actors. Check the cast list on IMDB.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@Primarus 
Also, the Director, Christopher Nolan, has said in interviews that there is a fact of﻿ the matter (in his mind) as to whether Cobb is in the "real world" in the final scene. However, he does leave it up to the viewer to figure it out. IMO, given I think the Wedding Ring Theory is correct and and things Nolan has said and written in his book, I believe Cobb makes it back to the "real world." But, it's still logically possible that Cobb is dreaming in the final scene.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@Primarus 
Again, if the top falls in the final﻿ scene, it doesn't prove that Cobb is in the real world (even though I believe he's in the real world in the final scene). For, he could be dreaming and imagining for the first time that it falls. He could be projecting the top and unconsciously willing it to topple over as he walks away from it. When the top was Mal's totem, she likely willed the top to behave in a continuous spin when she projected it in a dream.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@hazahaxa 
The reason why only around 15 years goes by for Cobb in Cobb's Limbo (as opposed to the 60 years for Saito) is because Cobb is a more experienced dreamer than Saito. So his mind is able to control the passage of Limbo time since he know's it's not the real world. But after a certain duration of Limbo time passes in his search for Saito, he starts to forget that Limbo isn't﻿ real. Plus, Saito ends up in Cobb's Limbo earlier than Cobb so a good deal of Limbo time has passed for him.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@hazahaxa 
You have this a bit confused. Both Saito and Cobb do not ride the synchronized series of double "Kicks" back because Saito is dead in dream level 1, 2 and 3 and lost in Limbo by the time they execute the synchronized double "Kicks" and Cobb doesn't jump off the ledge with Ariadne. Cobb and Saito can only escape Limbo when the sedative stops flowing into their arms which is about 9.5 hours in the real world and 60 years in limbo time for Saito and about 15 yrs in limbo time for Cobb.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@CaptainPriceLives 
That isn't Cobb's dad. That is Mal's dad, Stephen Miles. Mal's full name was Mal Miles. Stephen's wife is Marie Miles (who is looking after Cobb's kids, Phillipa and James). Nolan's book "Inception: The Shooting Script" confirms all of this. Moreover, Stephen Miles being at the airport to greet Cobb doesn't imply that Cobb is dreaming. Stephen flew from Paris to Los Angeles prior to Cobb and his team performing the inception job. He and Cobb planned it this way.

author: @hazahaxa
text: It has to be a simply because of how the "kick" works. They say throughout the film that when they have the kick it has to happen in all the dreams at the same time in order for them to wake up from it. All the kicks happen but Cobb and Saito are still in limbo. They missed the kick so they couldn't wake up. Also, it is heavily implied that they escape limbo by killing themselves with the gun, but we had already established dying in the dream would make them die in real life due to the sedative.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@doctorjones300 
Also, Nolan has conceded to his brother in the Intro to his book "Inception: The Shooting Script" that Mal is dead. So, it's not likely that Mal is still alive in the final scene - that she is possibly the architect and dreamer of some dream layer that Cobb is in. But if Mal is alive and her dream self is existing in this final scene and she somehow projects the top in Cobb's pocket and somehow removes the one Cobb usually projects, then, she could will it to continually spin.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@doctorjones300 
Again, if the top falls in the final scene, it doesn't prove that Cobb is in the real world (even though I believe, like you, that he is in the real world in the final scene). For, he could be dreaming and imagining for the first time that it falls. He could be projecting the top and unconsciously willing it to topple over as he walks away from it. When the top was Mal's totem, she likely willed the top to behave in a continuous spin when she projected it in a dream.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@wowcoolbang1 
Whoa! Not so quick. It's logically possible that it could all be one big dream from beginning to end. But there is a lot of visual evidence to suggest otherwise; also, studying Nolan's comments over the last 10 years reveals that he initially imagined a real world with real dream technology where a team of real dream thieves pull off a real dream heist against a real man, Fischer. So the story was grounded in the "reality" of this imagined world.

author: @SunsetSara
text:
@heisenberg1995 
You're right. This is another logical possibility that's been raised as well. Nolan may have intended it this way. What's interesting is that - there is a fact of the matter in Nolan's mind as to whether Cobb is in the real world at the end of the film. But he leaves it up to the audience to decide. I personally think the Ring is a visual clue for the audience, and I think Cobb is in the real world in the final scene - even though it's logically possible he is still dreaming.

author: @SunsetSara
text: Whether the top falls or not in the final scene doesn't prove whether Cobb is dreaming or﻿ not. He could very well be dreaming - imagining his children being two years older and in similar clothing to when he last saw them. The point of the ending scene is that, for Cobb, it doesn't matter whether the top falls or not. He walks away from it and doesn't care anymore. Whether he's in the "real world" or not is left to the viewer. I , for one, thinks he makes it back to the "real world."

author: @TylerBurgundy
text: If you truly loved this film, you wouldn't need to question whether it's a dream or not. It's fine to have an opinion, but Nolan has left it ambiguous to the audience for two reasons. Number one being that it's a happy ending, where Cobb has excepted his reality, one where he has forgotten the terrors of his wife and can freely see his kids. And number two being that Nolan, getting the response and questioning of 'Dream or Reality?', in a way has performed inception, an idea of how the film ends

author: @xMari95x
text:
@Cam1Deathsnake There are three theories to the top "not" stopping.

1) If you noticed, when Cobb spun the top in dreams, it always spun smoothly; at the end, it started to wobble.
2) The top was actually Mal's. and as the characters said, if someone else touched the totem, it would be void. Cobb touched Mal's totem making it void,  and the Chinese guard guy in limbo touched the top, also making it void. So whether it stopped or not wouldn't make a difference. 
3) His children were his totem.

author: @xMari95x
text:
Okay people. 

In dream sequences, Cobb had a wedding ring on. Does he have one on at the? No.

Some people say the children did not age. In the credits, they had two sets of children actors. If you watch the movie over, and pay attention, you can see at the end, the girl has white sleeves on her dress, the boy gets older, and they have different shoes. 

Also, the fact that Cobb is able to see his children's faces proves that its real.

author: @SpheriformLogic
text: Nolan's main idea for the ending of Inception was to show that Cobb no longer cares about Inception. All he wants to do is see his kids again and Nolan is showing us that he doesn't care about whether or not it is a dream or reality, he only cares about seeing his kids. The ending shows us he's left the dream world behind and moved on.

text: And remember when he said earlier that you always start in the middle of the dream.  But we see everyone wake up, we see him go through customs, Saito is on the phone, he talks to the father-in-law, everything is clearly set for him to go to his house, as opposed to just skipping straight there. author: @Snacks256
text: The top is wobbling.  If it were a dream, it would be spinning and making a constant whirring sound.  But it makes the distinctive sound of a wobbling top, especially just before it cuts out.  Additionally, he JUST established that the dream is not good enough for him.  Why would he go from rejecting projection Mal to accepting his kids?  Makes no sense.  Next, he would be making huge alterations, yet no one is attacking him and there are no signs of instability.

author: @ThePierreChannel
text: So the answer for ending is simple. It's the reality and It's the dream too. So Cobb would presently have a doubt whether his wife really died and whether this is really reality or not again. And he will do similar thing again(do "inception" for himself ) in order to return to the reality again unless he treats a world in front of him as the world satisfying him most. This resembles "Memento"...

author: @ThePierreChannel
text: So If the brain treats a world as fantasy, it's fantasy. If the brain treats it as the reality, it's the reality.(Nobody has ever watched God actually, but most people believe the existence of God.)That is, we treats a world satisfying us most as the reality. There are as many realities as the number of people. The quantum theory, such as  "Schrodinger's cat"  and  "Everett's many-worlds interpretation"  treats the world as such that.

author: @ThePierreChannel
text: Even if human perceives a physical phenomenon or a figment of the imagination by a letter and an image (for ex, dream,movie,TVshow,book etc), both of them are memorized as the information of the same quality in the cerebrum. This has been already proved in the brain science.So in fact, we're also in the world like INCEPTION. The brain cannot correctly distinguish whether it is reality or fantasy(dream)...

author: @EventuallyWeMerge
text: @mrcheesepuff01 The spinning top is a totem. A totem is a unique item to the individual dreamer that lets them know if they are in reality or dreaming. The dreamer knows the weight and feel of their totem and they don't let others touch it (save Cobb and his wife)......but if the top falls, it shows Cobb that he's in reality because that is basic physics....However, if the top keeps spinning, Cobb's world isn't based on real physics and therefore he/ is dreaming.

author: @JamieHowitt
text:
@darthnazgul 
True, I did some checking-up after I posted that. The ring can't be his totem, since it's basically nothing. He could use Mal's totem fine, since she's dead.
*BUT*

Totems only tell you if you're in someone else's dream, not if  you're in your own dream. So he might well be dreaming for the whole film - it doesn't matter if the top stopped spinning, because it won't tell him if he's in his own dream.

author: @JamieHowitt
text:
He's not dreaming!

In this scene, he's not wearing his wedding ring! The ring is his totem (the spinning top was his wife's, and you can't use someone else's totem). When he's awake, he doesn't have the ring and when he's dreaming, he does.

When he goes to hand over his passport, you briefly see his left hand. No ring. He's awake. Solved for sure.

author: @EventuallyWeMerge
text: So technically, his wife sees the totem fall, since she's the one facing them on the couch. It was HER totem, if any of you actually watched the movie. She's the one that had it locked away. Once she sees the totem fall at the end (which it does because it starts to wobble) she is finally out of Cobb's mind and he is permanently with his kids in Limbo. I can think of no better explaination, and I'd like to see anybody debate this. In other words, COBB was incepted to his benefit.

author: @EventuallyWeMerge
text: @333cale Nolan intentionally put the silhouette of his wife on the couch as he spins the totem. The whole POINT is that he chooses not to look at the projection. Some say it's a bunny, wtf? It's his wife laying on her side, face blurred out. He is stuck in his permanent Limbo because he chooses not to look at his wife OR the totem. He left both behind. It's like he goes to Heaven.....Because, if you don't make it out of Limbo, you are technically dead. That's what Nolan incepted into me.

i don't really understand how there is debate over whether the ending is dream or reality?
The fact that Cobb's totem wobbled means external forces were acting upon the totem, which in a dream would not be the relevant. This means because the totem was wobbling, it was beginning to fall, and would have fallen if we'd watched for any longer... they are therefore in reality.

Cobb also isn't wearing a wedding ring, and Michael Caine said that he only appeared in scenes that were reality...

author: @articianne
text: @MrSoloDoLocudii Actually I don't think it was twenty years, that's an extreme exaggeration. Perhaps two or three, maybe four or five. But in the ending, it was shown he forgot. He couldn't exactly remember what it was he was talking about, only that it was bothering him -- he was forgetting. (The years were in limbo -- the time is very very stretched over from real life time into limbo. So yes, it was minutes in real life while years in limbo.)

author: @dallasbagley
text: IMO, The best part of the film is when cobb opens his eyes in the airplane. It is in that moment that you realize they accomplished something that is almost certainly impossible.  Not just the planting of an idea, but the sheer odds that were stacked against them as a result of going 4 layers deep!  And it was bittersweet to see them go their separate ways at the end. Knowing that they will never meet again, but they will always share the single most incredible memory anyone could ask for.

author: @wHoiZEnIgMa
text: Cobb is obsessed with his spinning top. But, at the end, rather then wait to see the top fall (which would prove things are real), he just walks away. Why? He obviously could care less about 'true reality’ anymore. He just wants to be with his children, in whatever place he can be with them. This shows what nobody thinks about. Everyone is so preoccupied with working out whether he is in dream or reality to miss what the director possibly wanted to show. That it doesn't matter.

author: @EventuallyWeMerge
text: I dunno guys/gals.....I'm still convinced the whole 'Inception' was a ploy on Cobb. I mean, let's start from PERSONAL experience.....Haven't you guys ever had a dream in which you couldn't grasp something that kept slipping from you (an idea itself) and finally when you enter a deeper level of sleep you are able to grasp it? Maybe this is the point behind the whole movie....By planting the idea in Cobb's head that Fischer was incepted, this entire last sequence put him in the DEEPEST limbo ever.

author: @dallasbagley
text: P.S.  The totem fell.  You know why?  Cause Nolan is far too good of a director to say "fuck you" to the audience after that incredible roller coaster ride.  That's just not something a good story teller would do, straight up.  Never mind your theory's and ideas...  It's great that people are still talking about it, picking it a part etc.  Obviously, that was the intent...  But I'm telling you, there's NO way that totem didn't fall.  IMO, it would be an amateur mistake otherwise.

author: @dallasbagley
text: I was thinking about it last night, after watching this incredible, miracle of a movie.  And please don't crucify me for this...  By the idea of a prequel wouldn't be a terrible one...  Would it?  It would focus on Michael Caine's character, in his younger years.  And explain how the idea of "inception" was conceived, created etc.  As well, it would probably explore Caine's very first "inception", what went right, what went wrong, as well as how and why it got passed down to Cobb.
